class=\"module-widget article-top-widget\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n        <div class=\"access-state-logos all-viewports\">\r\n                    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    Magnified or multiply imaged? \u2013 Search strategies for gravitationally lensed supernovae in wide-field surveys\r\n<i class='' title='' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name js-linked-name-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\">Rados\u0142aw Wojtak</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    Rados\u0142aw Wojtak\r\n            <span class=\"info-card-footnote\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-cor1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"cor1\" data-open=\"cor1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-default\"><!----></a></span>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\">DARK, Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, Lyngbyvej 2, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-author-correspondence\">\r\n        E-mail: <a href=\"mailto:radek.wojtak@nbi.ku.dk\" target=\"_blank\">radek.wojtak@nbi.ku.dk</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-location\">\r\n        <a id=\"contrib-orcid-0000-0001-9666-3164\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9666-3164\">\r\n            <img class=\"orchid-icon\" alt=\"OrcId icon\" aria-hidden=\"true\"        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-internal\">\r\n    <a          </span>\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name Jens Hjorth\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-affilitation\">\r\n        <div class=\"aff\">DARK, Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, Lyngbyvej 2, DK-2100 id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n                          <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\"       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903433 id=\"136903433\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strongly lensed supernovae (SNe) can be detected as multiply imaged or highly magnified transients. In order to compare the performances of these two observational strategies, we calculate expected discovery rates as a function of survey depth in five <em>grizy</em> filters and for different classes of SNe (types Ia, IIP, IIL, Ibc, and IIn). We find that detections via magnification is the only effective strategy for relatively shallow pre-LSST (Large Synoptic Sky Survey) surveys. For survey depths about the LSST capacity, both strategies yield comparable numbers of lensed SNe. SN samples from the two methods are to a large extent independent and combining them increases detection rates by about 50\u00a0per\u2009cent. While the number of lensed SNe detectable via magnification saturates at the limiting magnitudes of LSST, detection rates of multiply imaged SN still go up drastically at increasing survey depth. Comparing potential discovery spaces, we find that lensed SNe found via image multiplicity exhibit longer time delays and larger image separations making them more suitable for cosmological constraints than their counterparts found via magnification. We provide useful fitting functions approximating the computed discovery rates for different SN classes and detection methods. We find that the Zwicky Transient Factory will find about two type Ia and four core-collapse lensed SNe per year at a limiting magnitude of 20.6 in the <em>r</em> band. Applying a hybrid method which combines searching for highly magnified or multiply imaged transients, we find that LSST will detect 89 type Ia and 254 core-collapse lensed SNe per year. In all cases, lensed core-collapsed SNe will be dominated by type IIn SNe contributing to 80\u00a0per\u2009cent of the total counts, although this prediction relies quite strongly on the adopted spectral templates for this class of SNe. Revisiting the case of the lensed SN iPTF16geu, we find that it is consistent within the 2\u03c3 contours of predicted redshifts and magnifications for the intermediate Palomar Transient Factory survey.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;supernovae: general&quot;\">supernovae: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903435 id=\"136903435\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The phenomenon of strongly lensed (multiply imaged) supernovae (SNe) has long been theoretically considered (Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>), but the first detections became possible only very recently. Quimby et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) found a strongly lensed Type Ia SN magnified by a factor of 30, although multiple images were not resolved. The first fully resolved image configuration of a lensed supernova was reported by Kelly et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The SN (SN Refsdal) was a core-collapse type (Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and lensed by an intervening galaxy cluster and a massive galaxy in the cluster. The second example of a fully resolved lensed SN was iPTF16geu (Goobar et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Detected as an exceptionally luminous SN (for its redshift) in a regular transient survey, the intermediate Palomar Transient Factory (iPTF), it was subsequently observed by ESO Very Large Telescope (VLT), Keck Observatory, and the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) whose images revealed a quadrupole lensing configuration with a subarcsecond scale of image separations. The SN was classified as a type Ia SN (Goobar et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Cano et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). High-cadence imaging of massive galaxy clusters with <em>HST</em> also recently resulted in the discovery of a new type of lensed transients which appeared to be strongly lensed individual stars (Rodney et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Kaurov et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strongly lensed SNe are unique objects in several respects, making them a promising tool for constraining cosmological parameters such as the Hubble constant (Grillo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Vega-Ferrero et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). With well-studied light curves, reasonably well represented by simple models, lensed SNe appear to be suitable for precise measurements of time delays from even relatively short observing campaigns (Rodney et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). If, in addition, a lensed SN is of Type Ia, extra constraints from the standard candle nature come into play. This can be used to measure magnification in an independent way (Rodney et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and thus provide additional constraints on the lens model. This extra information can potentially narrow down inherent degeneracies in lens models which leave all lensing observables invariant, except the time delay (Schneider\u00a0&amp; Sluse <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The unresolved degeneracies are the main source of potential systematic errors in cosmological constraints obtained from time-delay observations (Kolatt\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Oguri\u00a0&amp; Kawano <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strongly lensed supernovae will be found in large numbers and in a more automatic way in ongoing and future transient surveys (see e.g. Diego <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Two possible strategies for finding plausible candidates can be considered. One can search for multiply imaged supernovae (Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) or highly magnified (unresolved) transients (Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The former probes a unique feature indicating unambiguously the lensing nature of a candidate. The latter approach is less direct and involves an estimate of how much brighter an observed supernova is compared to a fiducial reference supernova, as it would have been observed in the lens galaxy (or the apparent host galaxy). Atypically bright supernovae in this case would indicate a high chance of observing a higher redshift, gravitationally magnified (amplified) supernova.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Searching for lensed supernovae via image multiplicity or magnification are the main observational strategies based on two characteristic features of the lensing phenomenon. The expected discovery rates have been estimated in several studies; however, each of them considering only one of the two methods and adopting specifications of upcoming surveys (Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Goldstein, Nugent\u00a0&amp; Goobar <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). At present, it is unclear to what extent the two methods are equivalent or complementary, which technique is more effective in finding lensed SNe in different ranges of limiting magnitudes or whether one would benefit from combining them. The two methods may differ not only in terms of their performance in finding candidates, but also in terms of the characteristics of the resulting lensed SN samples. This in turn raises the question which SN sample and thus which method would be suitable for robust measurements of time delays for the purpose of cosmological inference. In order to address these issues, we compute detection rates for both methods and a wide range of possible filters and SN types. This allows us to make the first comprehensive comparison of detection methods in terms of the discovery potential and the cosmological constraining power of the expected gravitationally lensed SN samples. We explore the possibilities of boosting discovery rates by combining the methods and we revisit the estimates of detections rates for ongoing and upcoming transient surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Estimating discovery rates of gravitationally lensed supernovae is not merely a means for quantifying the efficiency of detection methods. Lensed SNe can be also regarded as a cosmological tool probing a wide range of physical properties across cosmic time, e.g. volumetric rates and luminosity functions of SNe, lens models, or cosmological parameters. Observed detection rates can potentially shed light on some aspects of our current models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The paper is organized as follows. Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> outlines detection methods and the potential of increasing their discovery potential by combining them. We describe the computation of discovery rates as well as the underlying lens model and volumetric supernova rates in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. The results are presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a> followed by a discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and concluding remarks in Section 6. We adopt a flat \u039bCDM (\u039b cold dark matter) cosmological model with \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0= 0.3 and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0= 73\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903442 id=\"136903442\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONAL STRATEGIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The two main features through which strong lensing manifests itself are the multiplicity of images and the magnification of each image. Therefore, strongly lensed SNe can be detected and distinguished from ordinary non-lensed SNe if they appear as spatially and temporarily coincident transients (Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) or exceptionally bright transients (Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). In the following, we outline each observational strategy and the related detection criteria in more detail.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903444 id=\"136903444\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Image multiplicity</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The critical factors for detecting multiple images are the image separations relative to the seeing, the flux contrast between the images, and the apparent magnitudes of the faintest images in the configuration. As a base model for this strategy, we adopt detection criteria optimized for the Large Synoptic Sky Survey (LSST), as proposed by Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Following this approach, a transient is identified as a strongly lensed supernova if (i) the maximum image separation \u03b8<sub>max</sub> between images falls into a range between 0.5 and 4 arcsec, where these limits stem from seeing conditions as well as the choice of selecting systems lensed by isolated galaxies, characterized by relatively simple lens models, (ii) the flux ratio between the images for doubly imaged supernovae is larger than 0.1 and (iii) at least three or two images are detected for quads/cusps (four/three images) and doubles (two images), respectively. For sufficiently bright SNe and a suitable survey cadence, this strategy not only yields detections of multiply imaged SNe, but it also enables the measurement of basic lensing properties such as time delays and flux ratios between the images. In this respect, this is an ideal observational strategy for large and self-contained surveys such as the LSST. Initial information on lensing configurations can be also used to pin down the best candidates for follow-up observations.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903446 id=\"136903446\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 Magnification</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Strongly lensed supernovae can be detected as transients which appear significantly brighter than the brightest supernovae at the redshift of the apparent host galaxy (lens galaxy for lensed supernovae or actual host galaxy for non-lensed transients). Following Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the detection criterion can by formulated in the following way: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nm_{\\rm X}(t_{\\rm peak}) &amp; \\lt &amp; \\langle M_{\\rm X}\\rangle (t_{\\rm peak})+\\mu (z_{\\rm host})+\\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp; &amp; K_{\\rm XX}(z_{\\rm host},t_{\\rm peak})+\\Delta m, \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>m</em><sub>X</sub>(<em>t</em><sub>peak</sub>) is the observed peak magnitude of the transient in band <em>X</em>, \u3008<em>M</em><sub>X</sub>\u3009(<em>t</em><sub>peak</sub>) is a mean absolute magnitude of a reference class of brightest SNe in band <em>X</em> at peak, \u03bc is the distance modulus, <em>z</em><sub>host</sub> is redshift of the apparent host galaxy, <em>K</em><sub>XX</sub>(<em>z</em><sub>host</sub>, <em>t</em><sub>peak</sub>) is a <em>K</em>-correction for the assumed reference class of brightest supernovae at the peak of their light curves and \u0394<em>m</em> &lt; 0 is a free parameter defining the magnitude gap between lensed and non-lensed supernovae. Absolute magnitudes and <em>K</em>-corrections can be calculated from spectral templates of the assumed reference class of bright SNe, while the redshift of the apparent host galaxy can be estimated from existing photometric data from wide-field surveys. Since only rare cases of SNe are brighter than SNe Ia, e.g. superluminous SNe, it is reasonable to use type Ia as the reference class of bright SNe. Like Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we assume a mean peak absolute magnitude of \u221219.3 in the <em>B</em> band.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The choice of the parameter \u0394<em>m</em> is dictated by a trade-off between the completeness and the contamination of the selected lensed SN candidates. As a base model, we use \u0394<em>m</em>\u00a0= \u22120.7 required for distinguishing between the brightest non-lensed type Ia SNe and gravitationally lensed SNe (Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). We expect that the assumed magnitude gap is a sufficiently conservative choice from the point of view of minimizing the false positive rate. However, one has to bear in mind that rare luminous SNe brighter than \u221220 in the <em>B</em> band inevitably will be confused with lensed SNe in this approach.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The effective depth of a transient survey in the context of detecting strongly lensed SNe via magnification is modulated by the extent to which all lensing images contribute to the measured flux. It is natural to consider here two scenarios in which the total observed flux either comes from all images or is simply approximated by the flux of the brightest image. The former, which we adopt as our base model, sets an upper limit on the effective depth and discovery rates with respect to how efficiently the measured flux is integrated over all images. The latter determines the corresponding lower limits. We expect that most realistic detections in typical transient surveys will be intermediate between the two extremes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Compared to the strategy based on detection of multiple images, the competitiveness of this method heavily relies on follow-up observations. Higher resolution and deeper observations are necessary to both confirm the lensing nature of the candidates (by means of detecting multiple images) and determining the lensing configuration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although initially envisaged for finding strongly lensed type Ia SNe, the method can be also applied to detecting gravitationally lensed core-collapse SNe (Goldstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). Here, using type Ia SNe as the reference class of bright SNe sets a relatively conservative detection threshold. However, as we shall see, the higher volumetric rates of core-collapse SNe can compensate their lower luminosities leading to even higher discovery rates than for type Ia.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903452 id=\"136903452\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 Hybrid approach</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As we shall see in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, the two methods described perform very differently. The methods are complementary in many respects in that they maximize their efficiencies in different ranges of survey depth. This provides motivation for considering a third approach which combines the ideas underlying the two techniques. Here, a transient is classified as a lensed SN candidate if at least one of the two methods identifies it as a potential lensed SN.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903454 id=\"136903454\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 SIMULATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We employ a Monte Carlo approach to compute the expected number of observed strongly lensed SNe. The method relies on drawing random realizations of lens galaxies and SNe in a light-cone, and counting strong lensing events which satisfy certain detection conditions.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903456 id=\"136903456\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Lens galaxies</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Motivated by its success in modelling multiply imaged QSOs, we assume that the mass distribution in the lens galaxies is adequately represented by a Singular Isothermal Ellipsoid model (Kormann, Schneider\u00a0&amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>) in which the convergence \u03ba is given by: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update75119_equ2\" content-id=\"update75119_equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa (x,y) &amp; = &amp; \\frac{\\theta _{\\mathrm{ E}}}{2}\\frac{\\lambda (e)}{\\sqrt{(1-e)^{-1}x^2+(1-e)y^2}}, \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update165119_update75119_equ3\" content-id=\"update165119_update75119_equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\theta _{\\mathrm{ E}} &amp; = &amp; 4\\pi \\Big (\\frac{\\sigma }{c}\\Big)^{2}\\frac{D_{\\rm ls}}{D_{\\rm s}}, \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>where \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is the Einstein radius, \u03c3 is the line-of-sight velocity dispersion of the lens galaxy, <em>D</em><sub>s</sub> and <em>D</em><sub>ls</sub> are angular diameter distances, respectively, between the observer and the source, and the lens galaxy and the source. The convergence depends on the shape of the lens galaxy through the ellipticity <em>e</em> of the projected lensing mass surface density, which includes the contributions from dark matter and baryonic components, both relevant for the statistics of strong lensing images (Castro et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We assume that the ellipticity is given by the light distribution. Based on observational constraints, we adopt a Gaussian distribution for the ellipticity with a mean of 0.3 and dispersion of 0.16, with a truncation at 0.1 and 0.9 (Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The function \u03bb(<em>e</em>) is the so-called dynamical normalization and it depends on the deprojected shape of the lens galaxy. Following Chae (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), we assume that both oblate and prolate ellipsoids approximate the actual shapes of lens galaxies with equal probabilities, implying \u03bb(<em>e</em>) \u2248 1.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to make the simulated lensing more realistic, we account for the effect of the lens environment by including external shear (Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Witt\u00a0&amp; Mao <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Keeton, Kochanek\u00a0&amp; Seljak <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>) with a potential given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nV(x,y)=\\frac{\\gamma }{2}(x^{2}-y^{2})\\cos (2\\theta _{\\gamma })+\\gamma xy\\sin (2\\theta _{\\gamma }), \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where \u03b3 is the magnitude of the external shear and \u03b8<sub>\u03b3</sub> is its position angle on the image plane. We assume that \u03b3 follows a lognormal distribution with mean 0.05 and dispersion 0.2 dex, as expected for the external shear around early-type galaxies, calculated by ray tracing in cosmological simulations of the standard cosmological model (Holder\u00a0&amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). We expect that the employed simulation-based calibration of the external shear to a large extent accounts for lensing effects from realistic structures around lens elliptical galaxies, although the presence of a galaxy cluster may in addition affect the image configuration. The external shear in our model is uncorrelated with the orientation of the lens galaxy, i.e. it has a random orientation in the image plane.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We model the mass function of lens galaxies in terms of the velocity dispersion function of early-type galaxies, which are most common lens galaxies. The velocity dispersion function is well approximated by a modified Schechter function of the following form: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update75119_equ5\" content-id=\"update75119_equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\frac{\\mathrm{ d}n}{\\mathrm{ d}\\sigma }=\\phi _{\\star }\\Big (\\frac{\\sigma }{\\sigma _{\\star }}\\Big)^{\\alpha } \\exp \\Big [-\\Big (\\frac{\\sigma }{\\sigma _{\\star }}\\Big)^{\\beta }\\Big ]\\frac{\\beta }{\\Gamma (\\alpha /\\beta)}\\frac{1}{\\sigma }, \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>where <em>n</em> is the comoving density of galaxies. We use the above probability density to draw random realizations of lens galaxies in our calculations. We adopt parameters derived from fitting this model to the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) data (Choi, Park\u00a0&amp; Vogeley <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), i.e. <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\phi _{\\star } &amp; = &amp; 8.0\\times 10^{-3}h^{3}\\rm {Mpc}^{-3} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\sigma _{\\star } &amp; = &amp; 161\\, \\rm {km}\\, \\rm {s}^{-1} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\alpha &amp; = &amp; 2.32 \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\beta &amp; = &amp; 2.67. \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>Following Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we narrow the range of velocity dispersions to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(50\\, \\mathrm{ and}\\,400\\, \\rm {km}\\, \\rm {s}^{-1})$|</span> for galaxies which can effectively act as gravitational lenses. The lower limit coincides also with the minimum velocity dispersion measured from the SDSS spectroscopic observations.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We assume that the velocity dispersion function does not evolve with redshift. Although observational constraints on the velocity dispersion function are limited at high redshifts, this assumption is corroborated by existing data showing no evidence of redshift evolution at <em>z</em> \u2272 1, especially for the high velocity dispersion tail (Bezanson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Montero-Dorta, Bolton\u00a0&amp; Shu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The assumption is also supported by theoretical arguments based on the standard model for halo formation, for which Mitchell et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) showed that the normalization of the velocity dispersion function can be higher only by \u223c15\u00a0per\u2009cent at redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1, at which only rare galaxies can generate strongly lensed images of high-redshift SNe detectable in surveys with depths comparable to the LSST.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The number of lens galaxies in an observational cone as a function of redshift and velocity dispersion is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update75119_equ7\" content-id=\"update75119_equ7\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\frac{\\mathrm{ d}N_{\\rm lens}}{\\mathrm{ d}\\sigma \\mathrm{ d}z}=4\\pi \\frac{c}{H_{0}}\\frac{(1+z)^{2}D_{\\rm A}^{2}}{E(z)}\\phi (\\sigma), \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(7)</span></div>where <em>D</em><sub>A</sub> is the angular diameter distance, and <em>E</em>(<em>z</em>)\u00a0= <em>H</em>(<em>z</em>)/<em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is the dimensionless Hubble parameter. We note that the simulated redshift distribution of lens galaxies is independent of the Hubble constant adopted in our work and the only role of the assumed cosmological model is to extrapolate the redshift distribution from the redshifts of the main galaxy sample in the SDSS to higher redshifts.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903462 id=\"136903462\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Supernovae</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The total number of observed SNe per unit time as a function of redshift is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update75119_equ8\" content-id=\"update75119_equ8\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\frac{\\mathrm{ d}N_{\\rm SN}}{\\mathrm{ d}z}=4\\pi \\frac{c}{H_{0}}\\frac{(1+z)^{2}D_{\\rm A}^{2}}{E(z)}\\frac{1}{1+z}n_{\\rm SN}(z), \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(8)</span></div>where <em>n</em><sub>SN</sub>(<em>z</em>) is the volumetric SN rate in a local rest frame. Compared to equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update75119_equ7\"></span><a href=\"#update75119_equ7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>), the additional factor 1/(1 + <em>z</em>) accounts for a conversion from a local to the observer rest frame.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We compute the volumetric type Ia SN rate as the convolution of the delay time distribution <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm {DTD}}(t)$|</span> with the star formation history \u03c8(<em>t</em>), i.e. <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ9\" content-id=\"equ9\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nn_{\\rm SNIa}(t)=\\int _{0}^{t}\\psi (t-\\tau)\\rm {DTD}(\\tau)\\textrm{d}\\tau . \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(9)</span></div>For the star formation history, we employ a model from Madau\u00a0&amp; Dickinson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), based on a compilation of the cosmic star formation rates determined from ultraviolet (UV) and infrared (IR) observations: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ10\" content-id=\"equ10\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\psi (z)=0.015\\frac{(1+z)^{2.7}}{1+[(1+z)/2.9]^{5.6}}\\,\\,\\mathrm{M}_{\\odot }\\,\\,\\rm {yr}^{-1}\\,\\,h_{\\rm 70}\\,\\,\\rm {Mpc}^{-3}. \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(10)</span></div>Following Rodney et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), we assume that the delay time distribution is accurately described by the following piecewise function: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update85119_equ11\" content-id=\"update85119_equ11\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\rm {DTD}(t)= \\left\\lbrace \\begin{array}{ll}0 &amp; {\\rm {if}}\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,t\\lt 0.04\\,\\,\\rm {Gyr} \\\\\r\n\\eta _{1} &amp; {\\rm {if}}\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,0.5\\,\\,{\\rm {Gyr}}\\lt t\\lt 0.04\\,\\,{\\rm {Gyr}} \\\\\r\n\\eta _{0}t^{-1} &amp; {\\rm {if}}\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,t\\gt 0.5\\,\\,{\\rm {Gyr}} \\end{array}\\right. \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(11)</span></div>where \u03b7<sub>0</sub> and \u03b7<sub>1</sub> are free parameters. This model is well motivated by observations (Rodney et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Andersen\u00a0&amp; Hjorth <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) as well as theoretical arguments derived from the evolution of binary systems (Maoz\u00a0&amp; Mannucci <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). It accounts both for the population of prompt SNe with delay time <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$t\\lt 0.5\\,\\,\\rm {Gyr}$|</span> (with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$40\\,\\,\\rm {Myr}$|</span> as the shortest possible time before explosion, Belczynski, Bulik\u00a0&amp; Ruiter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) and delayed supernovae with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm {DTD}}\\propto t^{-1}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$t\\gt 0.5\\,\\,\\rm {Gyr}$|\u2060</span>. The two free parameters can be determined by fitting the model to the rates inferred from observations. We carry out the fit using a compilation of observational determinations of the volumetric type Ia SN rates from Graur et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) updated with the results from the Cosmic Assembly Near-infrared Deep Extragalactic Legacy Survey (CANDELS; Rodney et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Minimization of \u03c7<sup>2</sup> with errors including statistical and systematic uncertainties yields <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\eta _{0}=1.02_{-0.15}^{+0.27}\\times 10^{-4}\\,\\,h_{70}^{2}\\,\\,\\rm {yr}^{-1}\\,\\,{{{\\rm {M_{\\odot }}}}}^{-1}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\eta _{1}/\\eta _{0}=11.98^{+3.37}_{-4.49}$|\u2060</span>. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> compares the resulting best-fitting model to the observational data. The obtained constraints imply a fraction of prompt supernovae <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$f_{\\rm p}=0.63_{-0.11}^{+0.07}$|\u2060</span>, consistent with the results obtained by Rodney et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</div>                        <a id=\"136903465\" scrollto-destination=\"136903465\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=ncnmP3jpwiG2PC9FjSJpeC62-ERmyBnTLvLr7Binr0PiAhAEE3VcvdJ8VL4BrymPvljIncrKUGqFvXoMBgZV43D4npfrG3zKLtIb6BeTKUh~CJ2PorBndWhXKBS9IU3~9AnAiSST6ahgQjeEXKM9rua3-dTsTRDQvsh0~j1xuMGJtDcvblpfyGLxHic7uTCine67sdlIKtQKRIr0hS89bP8cWbGmiJcFwwmyph7LfUxMAtt7zC~fzYx~ivygLk6z3Xcgvxyl8O8EpFjSZuDwOHxW25zwrEQa8iHWFcbCMnS3yDeU38sQVKiiHvfHLSkwZJ0phhmqd~IDcV1RJU87Ew__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comoving volumetric rate of type Ia and core-collapse SNe assumed in our study. For core-collapse type, the rate is given by the star formation history from Madau\u00a0&amp; Dickinson (2014); for type Ia, the rate is the convolution of a delay time distribution given by equation\u00a0(11) with the adopted model of star formation history. Data points show observational measurements of the rate for type Ia, as compiled by Graur et\u00a0al. (2014). The various distinct symbols highlight selected results from CANDELS (Rodney et\u00a0al. 2014), the Supernova Legacy Survey (Perrett et\u00a0al. 2012), the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (Graur et\u00a0al. 2014), the Subaru Deep Field (Graur et\u00a0al. 2011) and the SDSS (Dilday et\u00a0al. 2010). Black symbols include results from Graur\u00a0&amp; Maoz (2013), Barbary et\u00a0al. (2012), Melinder et\u00a0al. (2012), Li et\u00a0al. (2011), Rodney\u00a0&amp; Tonry (2010), Botticella et\u00a0al. (2008), Dahlen, Strolger\u00a0&amp; Riess (2008), Dilday et\u00a0al. (2008), Horesh et\u00a0al. (2008), Blanc et\u00a0al. (2004), Tonry et\u00a0al. (2003), Pain et\u00a0al. (2002), Hardin et\u00a0al. (2000), and Cappellaro, Evans\u00a0&amp; Turatto (1999).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903465/stz1516fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903465\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=sBDqugc3zKOJqsEF5dLLiD1OF4FanhxQ107G6aC19KPdwLQnPcaYEDTvWreYsHWjq1afySk1FVpx2UOXEKgC6u8TmXf9twzbpZFZNsSC8n8Uq1GKoKUtetifLOEcb0oUqrpFSEN2-yCFjoQloIMSoYLBm9OdlmlumVaFNUJvnEw1iUZOWA-1-gCOqp3RbDogtlsRZRrZBTujriBXhZ6K9cbr5iOuniRWEWsCc2G9E21zxb8zrtLOVz~byMChArF77gHJKL9M3Obi2DdqZGRzJ5WE-R~CHEyoSOTNVex-57au3Z6K6d9GXS5NSscBdwTTOd8PG4FX-1L3DMX-NORc2w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903465&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comoving volumetric rate of type Ia and core-collapse SNe assumed in our study. For core-collapse type, the rate is given by the star formation history from Madau\u00a0&amp; Dickinson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>); for type Ia, the rate is the convolution of a delay time distribution given by equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update85119_equ11\"></span><a href=\"#update85119_equ11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">11</a>) with the adopted model of star formation history. Data points show observational measurements of the rate for type Ia, as compiled by Graur et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The various distinct symbols highlight selected results from CANDELS (Rodney et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), the Supernova Legacy Survey (Perrett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (Graur et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), the Subaru Deep Field (Graur et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and the SDSS (Dilday et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Black symbols include results from Graur\u00a0&amp; Maoz (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), Barbary et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), Melinder et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), Li et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), Rodney\u00a0&amp; Tonry (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), Botticella et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), Dahlen, Strolger\u00a0&amp; Riess (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), Dilday et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), Horesh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">(2008</a>), Blanc et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), Tonry et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">(2003</a>), Pain et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), Hardin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), and Cappellaro, Evans\u00a0&amp; Turatto <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">(1999</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=ncnmP3jpwiG2PC9FjSJpeC62-ERmyBnTLvLr7Binr0PiAhAEE3VcvdJ8VL4BrymPvljIncrKUGqFvXoMBgZV43D4npfrG3zKLtIb6BeTKUh~CJ2PorBndWhXKBS9IU3~9AnAiSST6ahgQjeEXKM9rua3-dTsTRDQvsh0~j1xuMGJtDcvblpfyGLxHic7uTCine67sdlIKtQKRIr0hS89bP8cWbGmiJcFwwmyph7LfUxMAtt7zC~fzYx~ivygLk6z3Xcgvxyl8O8EpFjSZuDwOHxW25zwrEQa8iHWFcbCMnS3yDeU38sQVKiiHvfHLSkwZJ0phhmqd~IDcV1RJU87Ew__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comoving volumetric rate of type Ia and core-collapse SNe assumed in our study. For core-collapse type, the rate is given by the star formation history from Madau\u00a0&amp; Dickinson (2014); for type Ia, the rate is the convolution of a delay time distribution given by equation\u00a0(11) with the adopted model of star formation history. Data points show observational measurements of the rate for type Ia, as compiled by Graur et\u00a0al. (2014). The various distinct symbols highlight selected results from CANDELS (Rodney et\u00a0al. 2014), the Supernova Legacy Survey (Perrett et\u00a0al. 2012), the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (Graur et\u00a0al. 2014), the Subaru Deep Field (Graur et\u00a0al. 2011) and the SDSS (Dilday et\u00a0al. 2010). Black symbols include results from Graur\u00a0&amp; Maoz (2013), Barbary et\u00a0al. (2012), Melinder et\u00a0al. (2012), Li et\u00a0al. (2011), Rodney\u00a0&amp; Tonry (2010), Botticella et\u00a0al. (2008), Dahlen, Strolger\u00a0&amp; Riess (2008), Dilday et\u00a0al. (2008), Horesh et\u00a0al. (2008), Blanc et\u00a0al. (2004), Tonry et\u00a0al. (2003), Pain et\u00a0al. (2002), Hardin et\u00a0al. (2000), and Cappellaro, Evans\u00a0&amp; Turatto (1999).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903465/stz1516fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903465\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=sBDqugc3zKOJqsEF5dLLiD1OF4FanhxQ107G6aC19KPdwLQnPcaYEDTvWreYsHWjq1afySk1FVpx2UOXEKgC6u8TmXf9twzbpZFZNsSC8n8Uq1GKoKUtetifLOEcb0oUqrpFSEN2-yCFjoQloIMSoYLBm9OdlmlumVaFNUJvnEw1iUZOWA-1-gCOqp3RbDogtlsRZRrZBTujriBXhZ6K9cbr5iOuniRWEWsCc2G9E21zxb8zrtLOVz~byMChArF77gHJKL9M3Obi2DdqZGRzJ5WE-R~CHEyoSOTNVex-57au3Z6K6d9GXS5NSscBdwTTOd8PG4FX-1L3DMX-NORc2w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903465&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comoving volumetric rate of type Ia and core-collapse SNe assumed in our study. For core-collapse type, the rate is given by the star formation history from Madau\u00a0&amp; Dickinson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>); for type Ia, the rate is the convolution of a delay time distribution given by equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update85119_equ11\"></span><a href=\"#update85119_equ11\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">11</a>) with the adopted model of star formation history. Data points show observational measurements of the rate for type Ia, as compiled by Graur et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The various distinct symbols highlight selected results from CANDELS (Rodney et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), the Supernova Legacy Survey (Perrett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (Graur et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), the Subaru Deep Field (Graur et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and the SDSS (Dilday et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Black symbols include results from Graur\u00a0&amp; Maoz (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), Barbary et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), Melinder et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), Li et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), Rodney\u00a0&amp; Tonry (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), Botticella et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), Dahlen, Strolger\u00a0&amp; Riess (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), Dilday et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), Horesh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">(2008</a>), Blanc et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), Tonry et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">(2003</a>), Pain et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), Hardin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), and Cappellaro, Evans\u00a0&amp; Turatto <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">(1999</a>).</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The rate of core-collapse SNe is directly proportional to the star formation history \u03c8(<em>z</em>): <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ12\" content-id=\"equ12\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nn_{\\rm SNCC}(z)=k_{\\rm CC}\\psi (z), \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(12)</span></div>where <em>k</em><sub>CC</sub> is the number of stars that explode as SNe per unit mass. For our study, we adopt <em>k</em><sub>CC</sub>\u00a0= 0.0068M<sub>\u2299</sub><sup>\u22121</sup> expected for a mass range of SN progenitors (8\u2009,\u200940\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>) and a Salpeter initial mass function. Since the same initial function was consistently assumed in the derivation of the star formation rate from observations, the predicted rate of core-collapse SNe is practically independent of the initial mass function (Madau\u00a0&amp; Dickinson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The resulting core-collapse SN rate is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We calculate light curves and <em>K</em>-corrections of simulated type Ia SNe (normal branch) using a time-series of spectral templates computed by Nugent, Kim\u00a0&amp; Perlmutter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). Following Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we assume that the absolute magnitude is normally distributed with a mean of \u221219.3 in the <em>B</em> band and a scatter of 0.2. We also check the impact of using a more realistic distribution with three\u00a0times longer Gaussian tail at low luminosities accounting for faint supernovae in volume-limited samples (see e.g. Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). For core-collapse SNe, we consider types Ib/c, IIP, IIL, and IIn, assuming that their relative contributions to the total number density of core-collapse SNe are independent of redshift and constrained by low-redshift observations resulting in 16, 49, 9, and 5\u00a0per\u2009cent respectively for Ib/c, IIP, IIL, and IIn (Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Graur et\u00a0al. 2017). We realize light curves of the four SN subclasses using spectral templates from a compilation which is an extension of the work by Nugent et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>),<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> based primarily on data from Levan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) for type Ibc, Di Carlo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) for IIn, and Gilliland, Nugent\u00a0&amp; Phillips (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) for the remaining two types. We approximate the distribution of absolute magnitudes in the <em>B</em> band by Gaussians with mean and scatter of \u221217.50 and 1.0 for type Ib/c, \u221216.70 and 1.0 for type IIP, \u221217.9 and 0.90 for type IIL, \u221218.5 and 1.0 (after discarding two outliers with <em>M</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0= \u221215.1, \u221222.2) for IIn (Richardson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014a</a>, for <em>h</em>\u00a0= 0.73). The assumed luminosity functions for all classes of SNe are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We note that the borderline between different classes may not be entirely clear cut. For example, there may be a continuous transition between type IIP and type IIL SNe (e.g. Anderson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). In this sense, these types can be seen as being representative for the fainter and more luminous ends of the type II SN population.</p>                        <a id=\"136903468\" scrollto-destination=\"136903468\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=N1pNGwu52iuhoIZUZL-d5Fi8lPoPDSiiQTAkjwREGFjWSKDX72qB1IyZndWTGOSnpztVfvHBCLkUhu8uguB2KRnZv8zrKGV2s4D~AEOZbku1cbIqETabjUN2u1KON6NfC7Hn0JrrMWa6mOqjSQjZGJOr7yeE7X88otsIKFv81UE1dEMF5QERC0zyYV9t4LwqPLAFqB5YFuz4GXsvbKzeV-Zql2BPa1y7XeVvXV5COQOzgZpIP~KU5ocw6gpFU4kVxye~qqHnPlWQHqCkss839ndZ533DRdaMER52usmy0GYBd~Sq-Ycq4~-sZH1nCGOw4calzYANV8eefmtdVePeDQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of absolute luminosities in the B band of the different types of SNe considered in our study. Normalizations of the distributions are proportional to the local volumetric rates of the correposnding SN classes. The green dashed curve shows an alternative model for type Ia SNe with with a tail accounting for low-luminosity SNe.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903468/stz1516fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903468\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=W792qvGFrA1vLRCeThQUwuL5ByMtvFzO6njXz0oYKzUAuXQWn79GKY9-Cu4fLwRI8hr1edjT0pJbDEUkYMbaZySIlCEHm5r~alYowrKBHzvdVUoM3cgKd0eVJ4wl053RYNl38Lx-Q1gbW77X8Hz0NaDqeDsoNiyJKhPD00QQu~~XL4s0lj2tpCN7rtmjWbfxshKWPf9dc~5SXCkAfj6OU9RyTn4nml9ye4i8V87IPYN1f~E0Z9uYyw8TFI727Wne1Kg6Z~bkXLnYbBe6d-nkh~yg7Irwdx~Qa44IguRCSl9Oto4y9HwlVZBtBGvE40l3ZdUnVSVjlQYPXAOO-hbgJw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903468&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of absolute luminosities in the <em>B</em> band of the different types of SNe considered in our study. Normalizations of the distributions are proportional to the local volumetric rates of the correposnding SN classes. The green dashed curve shows an alternative model for type Ia SNe with with a tail accounting for low-luminosity SNe.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=N1pNGwu52iuhoIZUZL-d5Fi8lPoPDSiiQTAkjwREGFjWSKDX72qB1IyZndWTGOSnpztVfvHBCLkUhu8uguB2KRnZv8zrKGV2s4D~AEOZbku1cbIqETabjUN2u1KON6NfC7Hn0JrrMWa6mOqjSQjZGJOr7yeE7X88otsIKFv81UE1dEMF5QERC0zyYV9t4LwqPLAFqB5YFuz4GXsvbKzeV-Zql2BPa1y7XeVvXV5COQOzgZpIP~KU5ocw6gpFU4kVxye~qqHnPlWQHqCkss839ndZ533DRdaMER52usmy0GYBd~Sq-Ycq4~-sZH1nCGOw4calzYANV8eefmtdVePeDQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of absolute luminosities in the B band of the different types of SNe considered in our study. Normalizations of the distributions are proportional to the local volumetric rates of the correposnding SN classes. The green dashed curve shows an alternative model for type Ia SNe with with a tail accounting for low-luminosity SNe.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903468/stz1516fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903468\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=W792qvGFrA1vLRCeThQUwuL5ByMtvFzO6njXz0oYKzUAuXQWn79GKY9-Cu4fLwRI8hr1edjT0pJbDEUkYMbaZySIlCEHm5r~alYowrKBHzvdVUoM3cgKd0eVJ4wl053RYNl38Lx-Q1gbW77X8Hz0NaDqeDsoNiyJKhPD00QQu~~XL4s0lj2tpCN7rtmjWbfxshKWPf9dc~5SXCkAfj6OU9RyTn4nml9ye4i8V87IPYN1f~E0Z9uYyw8TFI727Wne1Kg6Z~bkXLnYbBe6d-nkh~yg7Irwdx~Qa44IguRCSl9Oto4y9HwlVZBtBGvE40l3ZdUnVSVjlQYPXAOO-hbgJw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903468&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of absolute luminosities in the <em>B</em> band of the different types of SNe considered in our study. Normalizations of the distributions are proportional to the local volumetric rates of the correposnding SN classes. The green dashed curve shows an alternative model for type Ia SNe with with a tail accounting for low-luminosity SNe.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903469 id=\"136903469\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Computation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">First, we generate a random sample of lens galaxies at redshifts <em>z</em> &lt; 1.2. We find that it is sufficient to realize 10<sup>5</sup> lens galaxies and then rescale the final counts of strongly lensed SNe according to the actual number of lens galaxies contained in the assumed comoving volume. Then, we populate the observational cone up to redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3 with SNe. In order to reduce shot noise, we artificially increase the SNe rate by a factor of 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>5</sup>. The actual detection rate is then retrieved by scaling down the counts by the same factor. In order to save computational time (driven primarily by lensing computations), we discard all supernovae at angular distances larger than 4\u03b8<sub>E</sub>. These SNe are typically too far from the lenses to be multiply imaged or strongly magnified. Our choice of a maximum redshift for the lenses and the SNe allows us to determine detection rates of strongly lensed SNe for limiting magnitudes up to 26, which is around 2 mag deeper than the envisaged depth for the LSST.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For every lens\u2013supernova pair we calculate all basic lensing properties, i.e. image multiplicity, magnifications, positions of the images, and time delays. The lensing equations are solved numerically using the publicly available code for lensing calculations, <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). When calculating time-dependent apparent magnitudes, we take into account both the effects of magnification and time delay determined for every image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Once the complete Monte Carlo sample of strongly lensed SNe is computed, we can employ different detection criteria and thus determine the number of detectable lensed SNe as a function of survey depth in several different bands. This part of the calculations is independent of the assumed cosmological model and volumetric SN rates; therefore, it can be repeated for different detection criteria using the same pre-computed Monte Carlo sample of strongly lensed SNe and the corresponding lensing properties. The SN yields are computed for observations in five SDSS/LSST filters: <em>g, r, i, z</em>, and <em>y</em>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903473 id=\"136903473\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 RESULTS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903474 id=\"136903474\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Type Ia supernovae</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> compares detection rates for strongly lensed type Ia SNe expected for the three methods with the base choice of free parameters, as outlined in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. Our results demonstrate that the method based on detecting highly magnified SNe surpasses the image multiplicity technique for relatively shallow surveys with limiting magnitudes \u2272 22. In particular, for a survey with a 21 mag depth, the magnification method is expected to find \u223c20\u00a0times more strongly lensed SNe than the image multiplicity method. Due to the stronger dependence on the limiting magnitude for the image multiplicity method, this ratio becomes larger for even shallower surveys, with a threefold change per magnitude in the <em>i</em> band.</p>                        <a id=\"136903476\" scrollto-destination=\"136903476\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=v5ZM9BaTaZ47Gsw3L2H6keFnwfxSC-acagmqjCquILiqgk-PO0Iry868YRuOvVM~5DShY3PSRbYJSIGcCguJ0lXQbxou9qmZTiDebzRuRahh8KAzCHigwf9YfhbHlTn6kRCqRFmRgp~l2OXf9dKZXG4VXfaK~ZcLTE54Iwkst4DpVYFrEuCT95ncz6tz5AEmps6QmdBliwBWlA8EsFTQmQEgAjTPem9ADFeDLRPYHdlctu7g9tK-BO8nhDY-MD4jF3hSlPIV8gAENVWDRbI3jxZaZ9ecDnXhzMSyTWPYPcc41B7PYb5xii8GGUhhzNpYlsrxTRAHq8Xs8GGRwDqDcA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Detection rates of strongly lensed type Ia SNe as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SNe yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. The shaded band indicates the range of detection rates given by the extent to which flux is integrated over the SN images, with the upper and lower limits corresponding to the total measured flux from all images (upper limit) or solely from the brightest image (lower limit).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903476/stz1516fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903476\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=Cvn0t13fCO1cQlb16s2EMfRzNjIiFB~lWkTgGumbtE7axDyuwZdr79Q-sn4NlzkdnbV8V7gLFxFi-jpuwWJyA2JLqb8kojuT8qtAMYAVBiiVwMVx--iJEy8yqrTNasskHDI-0b-TNoX3ToffBJvhaLVh-GVKTWgUOdSMvry0qI0UgicOh1F8DszsJHXLQOFei3~0Hlqatn6U09tqIYIGyJjhQYmuFrsoQAh~0wxICXWa77fYFrwnQxCqFJ6gq8UjWLRxy6dCB0XG~GCT24bwCKN8Sh5rRMfA2Q3wG6JCcUu1BkdVvyEsxtNbSGd4~SSZd3zqOON7Ua-MAE3tP~qp~A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903476&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detection rates of strongly lensed type Ia SNe as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SNe yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. The shaded band indicates the range of detection rates given by the extent to which flux is integrated over the SN images, with the upper and lower limits corresponding to the total measured flux from all images (upper limit) or solely from the brightest image (lower limit).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=v5ZM9BaTaZ47Gsw3L2H6keFnwfxSC-acagmqjCquILiqgk-PO0Iry868YRuOvVM~5DShY3PSRbYJSIGcCguJ0lXQbxou9qmZTiDebzRuRahh8KAzCHigwf9YfhbHlTn6kRCqRFmRgp~l2OXf9dKZXG4VXfaK~ZcLTE54Iwkst4DpVYFrEuCT95ncz6tz5AEmps6QmdBliwBWlA8EsFTQmQEgAjTPem9ADFeDLRPYHdlctu7g9tK-BO8nhDY-MD4jF3hSlPIV8gAENVWDRbI3jxZaZ9ecDnXhzMSyTWPYPcc41B7PYb5xii8GGUhhzNpYlsrxTRAHq8Xs8GGRwDqDcA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Detection rates of strongly lensed type Ia SNe as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SNe yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria.
