The shaded band indicates the range of detection rates given by the extent to which flux is integrated over the SN images, with the upper and lower limits corresponding to the total measured flux from all images (upper limit) or solely from the brightest image (lower limit).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903476/stz1516fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903476\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=Cvn0t13fCO1cQlb16s2EMfRzNjIiFB~lWkTgGumbtE7axDyuwZdr79Q-sn4NlzkdnbV8V7gLFxFi-jpuwWJyA2JLqb8kojuT8qtAMYAVBiiVwMVx--iJEy8yqrTNasskHDI-0b-TNoX3ToffBJvhaLVh-GVKTWgUOdSMvry0qI0UgicOh1F8DszsJHXLQOFei3~0Hlqatn6U09tqIYIGyJjhQYmuFrsoQAh~0wxICXWa77fYFrwnQxCqFJ6gq8UjWLRxy6dCB0XG~GCT24bwCKN8Sh5rRMfA2Q3wG6JCcUu1BkdVvyEsxtNbSGd4~SSZd3zqOON7Ua-MAE3tP~qp~A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903476&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detection rates of strongly lensed type Ia SNe as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SNe yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. The shaded band indicates the range of detection rates given by the extent to which flux is integrated over the SN images, with the upper and lower limits corresponding to the total measured flux from all images (upper limit) or solely from the brightest image (lower limit).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For limiting magnitudes \u2273 23, increasing survey depth does not improve the performance of the magnification method, but it appreciably increases the rates for the other method. For deep surveys like the LSST, detecting multiple images appears to become a more powerful means for finding lensed type Ia SNe than gravitational magnification. The image multiplicity method is expected to yield about twice as many detections as the magnification method at a limiting magnitude of 24. The difference between the two methods becomes even more prominent for deeper surveys: the rates expected for the image multiplicity method increase exponentially with limiting magnitudes in a range between 24 and 26, whereas the rates from the magnification method become constant.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Both methods are expected to find comparable numbers of lensed type Ia SNe at limiting magnitudes between 23.0 in the <em>g</em> band to 23.8 in the <em>y</em> band. The lensed SN samples returned by the two methods happen to be only weakly overlapping; therefore, combining both detection criteria is expected to increase the yields, especially at intermediate limiting magnitudes. This is demonstrated by the solid curves which show detection rates for the hybrid method which identifies strongly lensed SNe either as highly magnified or multiply imaged transients. The hybrid method maximizes SN yields at all limiting magnitudes. Unsurprisingly, it follows closely the rates from the magnification method at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2272 21 and the image multiplicity technique at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2273 24.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The performance of the magnification method depends on the choice of the number of images that contribute to the total flux in the observations. The red band in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> shows the expected range of the rates modulated by this effect. The upper limit corresponds to detections based on flux integrated over all images, whereas the lower limit is expected for detections based on flux solely from the brightest image. The average ratio between the upper and lower limits is 2, with a very weak dependence on survey depth and filters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The apparent differences between detection rates from the two main methods reflect the fact that gravitational magnification and image multiplicity are not equally prominent features of strong lensing at different depths. The relatively poor performances of the magnification method for deep surveys (<em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &gt; 23) or the image multiplicity method for shallower surveys (<em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &lt; 23) cannot be appreciably improved by modifying the criteria for selecting the candidates. We demonstrate these intrinsic limitations in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, where we show supernova yields for different choices of the free parameters defining the detection criteria in the two methods. Reducing the magnitude gap \u0394<em>m</em> in the magnification method results naturally in a higher detection rate. However, the improvement is limited solely to magnitudes \u2273 22 where the method is clearly outperformed by the image multiplicity technique. Furthermore, this inevitably leads to a higher false positive detection rates due to intrinsically bright type Ia SNe.</p>                        <a id=\"136903481\" scrollto-destination=\"136903481\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=S4eeX1A4oYFjhNn9XFCljxvQuDO4MWWebAmeffn3a8m9ebcEsNSrtlmgLSiSIdyv1di1c4yKBx~U-0OmMWy63yenJLD7RPh5lR3tSuzTLXktjTsktF5eo8vWLb4z-hn8VUQWe3Rga70QjfL6NvwYggSGC1Y~BuLkJALAsPkaeaQTxbpKunstrcExYIG01EhlGHo~V2~tPXESXoFF2r8nX28VBIp7Fu3yimBsaPM~Wr7lrjoaOoxaTEQ81rBFCOnnb0AbRvvue4YEiyb~Afy8BQnU61V0R7GPkOg6WiXWcFlhm6APDnkOhOlqDsgINYhipaq9TOHVG2gsAtiMluQp-Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sensitivity of detecting lensed type Ia SN in the z band to parameters and conditions defining detection criteria of the two methods based on selecting highly magnified (red curves) or multiply imaged supernovae (green curves). The parameter \u0394m is a minimum enhancement of the apparent brightness due to lensing magnification relative to the mean magnitude of type Ia SNe expected in the apparent host (lens) galaxy (\u0394m\u00a0= \u22120.7 for the base model). For the image multiplicity method, discovery rates depend on the minimum number of detectable images. The solid and dashed curves compare the two cases for which at least three (base model) or two images are detectable for quads and cusps. The red dashed\u2013dotted curves shows the impact of accounting for the possible low-luminosity tail in the luminosity function dnSNIa/dMB of type Ia SNe (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a02) on the expected discovery rates.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903481/stz1516fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903481\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=IucYubcej5fv~xyaBGNnDY-6vbf5iDwmWYlDe95WgSqBN7ATPMsOUzMZNmLbINTZDWUSWOD2uw5UJj~~ofJxy~KUmp-lThclKHgJ1saSdFGyAUezGCZf0cm0piFb4UoQRFY~r7oqR9nE0UYUiMwFabQpiVBVn2xg~teJHPAfz3AMjMCb3pGu6iGk8ha5fsK1w4XYs~x3CkkKOtNnSs4690fHlo4HaUB6Y~LsjvBWbpp8vr3v0x9LsbIWW~72Cz1gEcMiRhGcSKak6OUSsWe16bj81C8JfE0iYGm~e5PQaFmOf7fboeSd1Zb1kShnc4s~j75JvRMzecRTsmjW4uwFFw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903481&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sensitivity of detecting lensed type Ia SN in the <em>z</em> band to parameters and conditions defining detection criteria of the two methods based on selecting highly magnified (red curves) or multiply imaged supernovae (green curves). The parameter \u0394<em>m</em> is a minimum enhancement of the apparent brightness due to lensing magnification relative to the mean magnitude of type Ia SNe expected in the apparent host (lens) galaxy (\u0394<em>m</em>\u00a0= \u22120.7 for the base model). For the image multiplicity method, discovery rates depend on the minimum number of detectable images. The solid and dashed curves compare the two cases for which at least three (base model) or two images are detectable for quads and cusps. The red dashed\u2013dotted curves shows the impact of accounting for the possible low-luminosity tail in the luminosity function d<em>n</em><sub>SNIa</sub>/d<em>M</em><sub>B</sub> of type Ia SNe (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) on the expected discovery rates.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=S4eeX1A4oYFjhNn9XFCljxvQuDO4MWWebAmeffn3a8m9ebcEsNSrtlmgLSiSIdyv1di1c4yKBx~U-0OmMWy63yenJLD7RPh5lR3tSuzTLXktjTsktF5eo8vWLb4z-hn8VUQWe3Rga70QjfL6NvwYggSGC1Y~BuLkJALAsPkaeaQTxbpKunstrcExYIG01EhlGHo~V2~tPXESXoFF2r8nX28VBIp7Fu3yimBsaPM~Wr7lrjoaOoxaTEQ81rBFCOnnb0AbRvvue4YEiyb~Afy8BQnU61V0R7GPkOg6WiXWcFlhm6APDnkOhOlqDsgINYhipaq9TOHVG2gsAtiMluQp-Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sensitivity of detecting lensed type Ia SN in the z band to parameters and conditions defining detection criteria of the two methods based on selecting highly magnified (red curves) or multiply imaged supernovae (green curves). The parameter \u0394m is a minimum enhancement of the apparent brightness due to lensing magnification relative to the mean magnitude of type Ia SNe expected in the apparent host (lens) galaxy (\u0394m\u00a0= \u22120.7 for the base model). For the image multiplicity method, discovery rates depend on the minimum number of detectable images. The solid and dashed curves compare the two cases for which at least three (base model) or two images are detectable for quads and cusps. The red dashed\u2013dotted curves shows the impact of accounting for the possible low-luminosity tail in the luminosity function dnSNIa/dMB of type Ia SNe (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a02) on the expected discovery rates.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903481/stz1516fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903481\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=IucYubcej5fv~xyaBGNnDY-6vbf5iDwmWYlDe95WgSqBN7ATPMsOUzMZNmLbINTZDWUSWOD2uw5UJj~~ofJxy~KUmp-lThclKHgJ1saSdFGyAUezGCZf0cm0piFb4UoQRFY~r7oqR9nE0UYUiMwFabQpiVBVn2xg~teJHPAfz3AMjMCb3pGu6iGk8ha5fsK1w4XYs~x3CkkKOtNnSs4690fHlo4HaUB6Y~LsjvBWbpp8vr3v0x9LsbIWW~72Cz1gEcMiRhGcSKak6OUSsWe16bj81C8JfE0iYGm~e5PQaFmOf7fboeSd1Zb1kShnc4s~j75JvRMzecRTsmjW4uwFFw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903481&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sensitivity of detecting lensed type Ia SN in the <em>z</em> band to parameters and conditions defining detection criteria of the two methods based on selecting highly magnified (red curves) or multiply imaged supernovae (green curves). The parameter \u0394<em>m</em> is a minimum enhancement of the apparent brightness due to lensing magnification relative to the mean magnitude of type Ia SNe expected in the apparent host (lens) galaxy (\u0394<em>m</em>\u00a0= \u22120.7 for the base model). For the image multiplicity method, discovery rates depend on the minimum number of detectable images. The solid and dashed curves compare the two cases for which at least three (base model) or two images are detectable for quads and cusps. The red dashed\u2013dotted curves shows the impact of accounting for the possible low-luminosity tail in the luminosity function d<em>n</em><sub>SNIa</sub>/d<em>M</em><sub>B</sub> of type Ia SNe (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) on the expected discovery rates.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relaxing the selection criteria for the image multiplicity method by including all systems with at least two detectable images (for all images configurations) improves the SN yields only at small limiting magnitudes, e.g. by a factor of 4 at <em>z</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2248 21 (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). The resulting detection rates, however, are still smaller than those of the magnification method. Since the selection criterion cannot be relaxed even further, this case sets an upper limit for the expected detection rates based on image multiplicity. Finally, we find that changing the range of the maximum image separation does not appreciably modify the predictions for the lensed supernova yields.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A strong limitation of the magnification method is reflected by a plateau at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2273 22.5 which signifies that the method does not benefit from increasing survey depth. This feature is an unavoidable drawback of the method and it cannot be removed by simply adjusting \u0394<em>m</em> (subject to a reasonable condition \u0394<em>m</em> &lt; 0). It is primarily caused by the fact that high-redshift lenses and SNe require extremely large, and therefore improbable, magnifications in order to fall within a range of detectable fluxes. We illustrate this in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> which compares selections of lensed SN candidates in shallow (<em>i</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 21) and deep (<em>i</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 25) surveys. Faint, high-redshift SNe are not sufficiently magnified in order to be selected by the magnification method. Most of them happen to be fainter than a fiducial reference type Ia SN with absolute luminosity <em>M</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0= \u221220 that would be observed in the apparent host galaxy (actual lens galaxy). On the other hand, faint SNe from deep surveys appear to exhibit relatively brighter secondary images than those from shallow surveys. This makes the image multiplicity method more effective in selecting lensed SN candidates in deep surveys at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2273 23.5.</p>                        <a id=\"136903484\" scrollto-destination=\"136903484\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=sQIQCfhO5byD2atl0F8lSVCxZtLOgbun7Gn7WhFfy2OmYB-cLuNGzyB3--~sD8IgKuzVKz0s-k0ycHuNWdgK~xDnoiN3WRpLa7Fc2CyotMKHBdz9YtKFxaT377UtkGFSQA17fEGZfs6dgrQZ17lT4th026irfHuCQNJGBTKZCIC0HmMgtwzHCwQ02P6FO26n2rE4JMdQdQfO5BQ1LNi-oWwkl1eC7klyljkXZrPxGi88z4TiltqhkXf3GB3UnQQO11mMded1efjLrxwd0lwMzEVTy5Jcoow6~qY1J~aSJR7MAC7SlZr7rpObXNfsmVqnc2tzABitdEq~dkGw7ZzA9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Selection of lensed SN candidates (using type Ia as an example) by means of finding highly magnified transients, i.e. brighter than a fiducial type Ia SNe observable in the apparent host (actual lens) galaxy (see the red arrow and the indicated shaded region), or detecting the second brightest image (see the blue arrow arrow and the indicated shaded region). The two contours show the distribution of all observable lensed SNe in two surveys with depths of 21 and 25 in the i band. The majority of bright, low-redshift SNe appear to be highly magnified, but featuring the secondary image beyond detection limits (purple contours). They can be found using primarily the magnification method. On the other hand, the majority of faint, high-redshift lensed SNe from a deep survey (green contours) are not sufficiently magnified to be detected as peculiarly bright supernovae, but they exhibit detectable second brightest images. These lensed SNe can be effectively found as doubly imaged transients.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903484/stz1516fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903484\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=GXK8SFzXFOZ2QauvdYKVM6XsPjZ-1ixEFcHa15C7bRvk9BefKTrfAgUonN9f~WAYbSpfmFF9O-BBpygfm3n0WEt6kKQX2ghjB-jKwMPr7RgKid7GVk71kvivN8GLCGwkFFsdQruKCTPKdJsCr-5hX1idjuE3el~7-25KCo6jaU6hDNmj0E3j5tM6g0AjjlVrI48NYBTTU7gyDaBqnPUDDljt1zj3hJ-MWURcXhB3Tm7E1aU-t9LqcMi7nJsD6H0XSrcpzAY6NbZuokYaPYP21ZB7noAGh9qPtSdhombsjbl0C5b-HmtxBhix8CaZUNazTRre1ostEl2xi1ssVEIWgg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903484&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Selection of lensed SN candidates (using type Ia as an example) by means of finding highly magnified transients, i.e. brighter than a fiducial type Ia SNe observable in the apparent host (actual lens) galaxy (see the red arrow and the indicated shaded region), or detecting the second brightest image (see the blue arrow arrow and the indicated shaded region). The two contours show the distribution of all observable lensed SNe in two surveys with depths of 21 and 25 in the <em>i</em> band. The majority of bright, low-redshift SNe appear to be highly magnified, but featuring the secondary image beyond detection limits (purple contours). They can be found using primarily the magnification method. On the other hand, the majority of faint, high-redshift lensed SNe from a deep survey (green contours) are not sufficiently magnified to be detected as peculiarly bright supernovae, but they exhibit detectable second brightest images. These lensed SNe can be effectively found as doubly imaged transients.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=sQIQCfhO5byD2atl0F8lSVCxZtLOgbun7Gn7WhFfy2OmYB-cLuNGzyB3--~sD8IgKuzVKz0s-k0ycHuNWdgK~xDnoiN3WRpLa7Fc2CyotMKHBdz9YtKFxaT377UtkGFSQA17fEGZfs6dgrQZ17lT4th026irfHuCQNJGBTKZCIC0HmMgtwzHCwQ02P6FO26n2rE4JMdQdQfO5BQ1LNi-oWwkl1eC7klyljkXZrPxGi88z4TiltqhkXf3GB3UnQQO11mMded1efjLrxwd0lwMzEVTy5Jcoow6~qY1J~aSJR7MAC7SlZr7rpObXNfsmVqnc2tzABitdEq~dkGw7ZzA9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Selection of lensed SN candidates (using type Ia as an example) by means of finding highly magnified transients, i.e. brighter than a fiducial type Ia SNe observable in the apparent host (actual lens) galaxy (see the red arrow and the indicated shaded region), or detecting the second brightest image (see the blue arrow arrow and the indicated shaded region). The two contours show the distribution of all observable lensed SNe in two surveys with depths of 21 and 25 in the i band. The majority of bright, low-redshift SNe appear to be highly magnified, but featuring the secondary image beyond detection limits (purple contours). They can be found using primarily the magnification method. On the other hand, the majority of faint, high-redshift lensed SNe from a deep survey (green contours) are not sufficiently magnified to be detected as peculiarly bright supernovae, but they exhibit detectable second brightest images. These lensed SNe can be effectively found as doubly imaged transients.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903484/stz1516fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903484\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=GXK8SFzXFOZ2QauvdYKVM6XsPjZ-1ixEFcHa15C7bRvk9BefKTrfAgUonN9f~WAYbSpfmFF9O-BBpygfm3n0WEt6kKQX2ghjB-jKwMPr7RgKid7GVk71kvivN8GLCGwkFFsdQruKCTPKdJsCr-5hX1idjuE3el~7-25KCo6jaU6hDNmj0E3j5tM6g0AjjlVrI48NYBTTU7gyDaBqnPUDDljt1zj3hJ-MWURcXhB3Tm7E1aU-t9LqcMi7nJsD6H0XSrcpzAY6NbZuokYaPYP21ZB7noAGh9qPtSdhombsjbl0C5b-HmtxBhix8CaZUNazTRre1ostEl2xi1ssVEIWgg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903484&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Selection of lensed SN candidates (using type Ia as an example) by means of finding highly magnified transients, i.e. brighter than a fiducial type Ia SNe observable in the apparent host (actual lens) galaxy (see the red arrow and the indicated shaded region), or detecting the second brightest image (see the blue arrow arrow and the indicated shaded region). The two contours show the distribution of all observable lensed SNe in two surveys with depths of 21 and 25 in the <em>i</em> band. The majority of bright, low-redshift SNe appear to be highly magnified, but featuring the secondary image beyond detection limits (purple contours). They can be found using primarily the magnification method. On the other hand, the majority of faint, high-redshift lensed SNe from a deep survey (green contours) are not sufficiently magnified to be detected as peculiarly bright supernovae, but they exhibit detectable second brightest images. These lensed SNe can be effectively found as doubly imaged transients.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to show more quantitatively the differences between the magnification and image multiplicity methods of selecting lensed SNe candidates, we calculate the completeness of lensed SN searches as a function of survey depth (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). We define the 100\u00a0per\u2009cent complete reference sample as consisting of all observable/detectable lensed type Ia SNe, i.e. all multiply imaged type Ia SNe that are brighter than <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> at the peak of their light curves in at least one of the five bands, where apparent magnitudes are computed by integrating flux over all images. The figure shows that the magnification method maximizes its completeness for shallow surveys, with completeness reaching 80\u00a0per\u2009cent at \u2272 21.5 mag in the <em>z</em> or <em>y</em> band, and then it degrades at large survey depths. An inverse trend characterizes the completeness of the image multiplicity method which becomes more complete with increasing survey depth, reaching about 40\u00a0per\u2009cent at 25 mag in the <em>y</em> or <em>z</em> bands. The solid curves show the completeness of the hybrid method. It is evident that combining the magnification and the image multiplicity detection criteria improves the completeness at limiting magnitudes characteristic for the LSST, i.e. 22 &lt; <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &lt; 24. In particular, the hybrid method boosts the completeness by about 50\u00a0per\u2009cent in the <em>y</em> band relative to lensed SN searches based solely on the magnification or image multiplicity criterion. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> demonstrates also a difference between the magnification and image multiplicity methods in terms of redshift completeness. While the magnification technique can never be more complete than 20\u00a0per\u2009cent at all redshifts, the image multiplicity method attains an 80\u201390\u00a0per\u2009cent completeness up to a maximum redshift set by the survey depth.</p>                        <a id=\"136903486\" scrollto-destination=\"136903486\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=4jjO1R5gWuTgiHRAKn~2ncoZh7CRFptA5wXhqtIjYCEzdaI~Ox00IaempsPujtb-Doff3opc9vUYdBETyltnNXJJnoXl-KHRBrbiNkOSdXuu-bA1-icLlXaJAXpUynR4yXpbE8kgTKUA-1lAMYFApjz92NGPmJzcAf~OshdbxknR1Z5t8BoQKBGOiabbInUwYFGFBwisXUSHAegxX-Nxb8vUlqSqsHjvA0wVMFCuS2Ivz0gtQWNfB-ficc5DN6uNqnzNoVe8V6MJnT7xl7lw5B1VA-fBrJTbQ3FXqLek3llW2EXHcZ3jg9tn7RpoHJT3fHTRuLrTja4KHG1-rqtPvw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Completeness of lensed SN candidates found with three different methods, as a function of survey depth in five different bands. The vertical grey bands indicate the depths of ZTF and LSST. The method based on detecting highly magnified supernovae reaches an \u223c80\u00a0per\u2009cent completeness in the z and y bands at Xlim &lt; 21. The completeness of lensed SNe search by means of detecting image multiplicity increases with survey depth. The method becomes more complete than that based on magnification for surveys with depths comparable to or larger than the LSST.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903486/stz1516fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903486\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=PUGf36XJSpQAjOJWK8YzEMJd9-2IwangooCsbk~AXXo~VW9scaDZMrSY0cgTXWXkKoe2vUs6XSXjN3OMzjgmQ4UFVceYq40CG6fDjpnnkspvc1M2OWwpZDXzbdbFKi-28RpCImKtiHV8oKiiVfFUr1cgnzxWrzRD42UgZlOE4-Og3ujOTE-skvnFb6G2S4g6eTuvoD1TNgr02poh92uJGKWYnmUI2JLXq9WILXCavNxolwlSzCIBxAHt3dlU-fmEjUuXwlKryapqoSQNDTfcVJseYwUijeDn1LEk6UuC9WFY-1-T86ZelzLWMWwXFdAmPZxj3B68SI7TCBcNIXhYPQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903486&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Completeness of lensed SN candidates found with three different methods, as a function of survey depth in five different bands. The method based on detecting image multiplicity returns nearly complete redshift samples up to a maximum redshift set by the survey depth. For a reference point, the black curves show redshift distributions of all (non-lensed) or strongly lensed type Ia SNe, both normalized to 1 at z &lt; 3.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903487/stz1516fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903487\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=fG-c5VJV0IdSOkqf1afLgACWc6kjhhGEpBX3rothW6HHnzGvgYokgpod4rmMnRWtgwk-V7TgniumMc1mofYQj8uHHdasf-VudIbDrzHYiO3Y-UazfCVYzMgU078wxkYT325dn4oxO8TNSQlFvPL3kCEBOT4a2jQAOI9yJQ9G~yJm2SbdWpYdoptYldg2MDjTuIhiymXsIwTK5wcL9FvJlg9lOV3d5G8HZs~2X0CiX1Pg~Ga~d37By9mMCFiNjiXBkybcqmm4wOVNoAOM8gPLlOHaDTu0QQdPqbV1yD9V04tdALsda-KmjLDH9SB~7eoZIPBGRs1d6IMYv9Mr4hfU4A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903487&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift completeness of lensed type Ia SN candidates found with three different methods, for three limitting magnitudes <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band. The method based on detecting image multiplicity returns nearly complete redshift samples up to a maximum redshift set by the survey depth. For a reference point, the black curves show redshift distributions of all (non-lensed) or strongly lensed type Ia SNe, both normalized to 1 at <em>z</em> &lt; 3.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903488 id=\"136903488\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Core-collapse supernovae</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, we show the expected detection rates for lensed core-collapse SNe, divided into four subclasses. As for Type Ia SNe, the method of finding lensed SNe by means of detecting highly magnified transients appears to be more effective for shallow surveys, but it is surpassed by the technique based on image multiplicity for deep surveys. The limiting magnitude of comparable performances of the two methods depends weakly on the SNe type and filter, and it typically falls within a magnitude range between 23 and 24. The exception in this respect are type IIn SNe for which the magnification-based method appears to be more effective up to as high as 25 mag in the <em>g</em> and <em>r</em> bands.</p>                        <a id=\"136903490\" scrollto-destination=\"136903490\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=FQAvSB3E7cVcQUfim9CGa~iUs94Yv8yIa0nTbfC5bTlba8HwSV7RJOMCIe-S206MWfRxsk~Zp7t-yaC3xenZttGbPn30A3g1ESjhCioH5qqb8fQvqM09CDRQL-o4zIRM0q8~EP1vlw2njNpGahUamGipiFwiMfP~7UrIYxISdPbCgNDRLqaBdD7GpVn7nHflKYJ~uQ5bkF10gSZnsH2VuOYsxBBu1uWK8qL0FTZo3UOFhdglDJc4S5dZ4GMxEYWvfUSFLVp3c4s3YnkZdhgVPjd3wwjBOj55qdGj00ZYSpi60HWl~1nADE8vDZ8GDlBXWLqIzV~dTl5t14mUmAEffA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Detection rates of strongly lensed core-collapse SNe (from top left clockwise: IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ibc) as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SN yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. For comparison, the orange curves shows the expected rates for lensed type Ia SNe observed in the i band.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903490/stz1516fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903490\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=MIg1LXYmOIpXghlaaAcxFIdXBVO3lBN1R~6~lD81c8~z5DgabRVlX6Wez2i6c60ejmIERJCG4itAz0p4RsYNHm-hRI5wEL-gKd-X2rlowQy6bsr~UbQmuTDHqcoEor836QJxd6DvV2TvtJYRBmBh7~2v8e~9Rp3hylzt~Isvm8Yfh7vCrenEAxJtHoJpD2gogdTqHopjmHIHTJ0eJfaK0VXme2HvQRzgvcVX8CDr4D2Ylw77iM8JdE2Th73NNPs0a4nUnSNVK4Nhmy7sdBZXEwLPWliwhlJfaeLHRyEXpFqz6ufMuExhqVtT43F35PIvGfT2BTwTpdZjarhpcy4IVg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903490&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detection rates of strongly lensed core-collapse SNe (from top left clockwise: IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ibc) as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SN yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. For comparison, the orange curves shows the expected rates for lensed type Ia SNe observed in the <em>i</em> band.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=FQAvSB3E7cVcQUfim9CGa~iUs94Yv8yIa0nTbfC5bTlba8HwSV7RJOMCIe-S206MWfRxsk~Zp7t-yaC3xenZttGbPn30A3g1ESjhCioH5qqb8fQvqM09CDRQL-o4zIRM0q8~EP1vlw2njNpGahUamGipiFwiMfP~7UrIYxISdPbCgNDRLqaBdD7GpVn7nHflKYJ~uQ5bkF10gSZnsH2VuOYsxBBu1uWK8qL0FTZo3UOFhdglDJc4S5dZ4GMxEYWvfUSFLVp3c4s3YnkZdhgVPjd3wwjBOj55qdGj00ZYSpi60HWl~1nADE8vDZ8GDlBXWLqIzV~dTl5t14mUmAEffA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Detection rates of strongly lensed core-collapse SNe (from top left clockwise: IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ibc) as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SN yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. For comparison, the orange curves shows the expected rates for lensed type Ia SNe observed in the i band.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903490/stz1516fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903490\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=MIg1LXYmOIpXghlaaAcxFIdXBVO3lBN1R~6~lD81c8~z5DgabRVlX6Wez2i6c60ejmIERJCG4itAz0p4RsYNHm-hRI5wEL-gKd-X2rlowQy6bsr~UbQmuTDHqcoEor836QJxd6DvV2TvtJYRBmBh7~2v8e~9Rp3hylzt~Isvm8Yfh7vCrenEAxJtHoJpD2gogdTqHopjmHIHTJ0eJfaK0VXme2HvQRzgvcVX8CDr4D2Ylw77iM8JdE2Th73NNPs0a4nUnSNVK4Nhmy7sdBZXEwLPWliwhlJfaeLHRyEXpFqz6ufMuExhqVtT43F35PIvGfT2BTwTpdZjarhpcy4IVg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903490&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detection rates of strongly lensed core-collapse SNe (from top left clockwise: IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ibc) as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SN yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. For comparison, the orange curves shows the expected rates for lensed type Ia SNe observed in the <em>i</em> band.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The orange curves in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> show reference rates for lensed type Ia SNe detectable in the <em>i</em> band. Except for type IIn SNe, the discovery rates of lensed core-collapsed SNe are lower than type Ia by a factor of 2\u20135. A high fraction of luminous type IIn SNe with <em>M</em><sub>B</sub> &lt; \u221220 makes them appreciably easier to detect. Furthermore, the high UV flux of these SNe substantially increases the detection rates in shorter wavelength filters. This considerably reduces the differences between detection rates in the <em>g</em> and <em>y</em> bands, which is otherwise conspicuous for all other SN types. This effect becomes particularly strong at large limiting magnitudes (<em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &gt; 23.5), where the <em>g</em> band appears to be the most effective filter for detecting lensed type IIn SNe via the magnification method.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The total number of detectable lensed core-collapse SNe exceeds that of type Ia, with the primary contribution coming solely from type IIn SNe. The detection rates of lensed SNe of type IIP, IIL, and Ib/c are systematically lower than type Ia.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903493 id=\"136903493\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Fitting function</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For the purpose of future studies exploring the feasibility of using strongly lensed SNe as cosmological and astrophysical probes, we provide a set of simple fitting functions reproducing the computed detection rates. We find that the logarithm of detection rates can be well fitted by a fourth-degree polynomial, i.e. <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update85119_equ13\" content-id=\"update85119_equ13\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\log _{10}n_{\\rm SN}(\\lt X_{\\rm lim}) &amp; = &amp; \\sum _{i=0}^{i=4}X_{\\mathrm{ i}}(X_{\\rm lim}-22.5)^{i}. \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(13)</span></div>Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> lists best-fitting parameters for different detection strategies, SN types, and filters.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The fitting functions provide accurate approximations to the exact results in a range between <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 19 and 26 for all cases. The mean precision given by the root mean square averaged over all cases of filters, SN types, and methods is 0.02\u00a0dex.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903496 id=\"136903496\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected detection rates of strongly lensed SNe computed in our work depend on a range of assumptions. The cosmological model, the lens model, and the volumetric rates of type Ia SNe are fairly well constrained by observations and supported by solid theoretical frameworks. On the other hand, the luminosity functions and fractions of different types of SNe, the volumetric rates of core-collapse SNe at high redshifts and the spectral templates of different types of core-collapse SNe (especially type IIn) are less certain and may be a source of additional systematic errors in our estimates. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> shows an example of how modifications in the input luminosity function of type Ia SNe can change the expected discovery rates. Bearing in mind that our results may be subject to improvements in the light of future observations, we stress that the predicted discovery rates of lensed SNe presented here reflect the current state of our knowledge on different types of SNe.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In our calculations, we neglect the effect of microlensing. This is a safe assumption, because due to its stochastic nature, microlensing is expected to have a negligible impact on overall predictions of discovery rates of lensed SNe (Goldstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). However, the effect does perturb light curves independently in every supernova image, giving rise to additional systematic errors in measurements of relative fluxes in the images and time delays (Pierel\u00a0&amp; Rodney <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). In our comparison of detection methods we do not consider the problem of possible false positive detections. All methods will be affected by a population of faint quasars increasing stochastically their brightness above the detection limit. Moreover, the magnification method can easily confuse non-lensed superluminous SNe with high-redshift lensed candidates. Quantitative analyses of these effects is worth carrying out in the near future.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the following, we compare observational strategies for detecting lensed supernovae in the context of ongoing or upcoming transient surveys and the potential of using lensed SNe for cosmological inference.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903500 id=\"136903500\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Ongoing and upcoming surveys</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strongly lensed SNe will be discovered in appreciable numbers by ongoing and upcoming transient surveys. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists the expected discovery rates for the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), LSST, and a hypothetical the Panoramic Survey Telescope and Rapid Response System (Pan-STARRS) survey.</p>                        <a id=\"136903502\" scrollto-destination=\"136903502\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected <em>annual</em> numbers of discovered lensed supernovae in ongoing or upcoming transient surveys. The method based on image multiplicity is ineffective in case case of ZTF and Pan-STARRS, and thus it is omitted in the table. Symbols in parentheses indicate the most effective filter yielding the largest number of detections.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Survey/detection method<span (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/magnification\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>61(<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.2 (<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>8.7 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.3 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>184 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/image multiplicity\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>44 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.1 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>5.5 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>88 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/hybrid\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>89 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>16.3 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>11.9 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>15.8 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>210 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Survey/detection method<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Effective area (deg<sup>2</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ia<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIP<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIL<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ib/c<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIn<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>ZTF/magnification\u00a0</td><td>15 000\u00a0</td><td>2.1 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.37 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.23 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.36 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>3.8 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Pan-STARRS/magnification\u00a0</td><td>3000\u00a0</td><td>0.9 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.20 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.13 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.20 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/magnification\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>61(<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.2 (<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>8.7 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.3 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>184 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/image multiplicity\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>44 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.1 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>5.5 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>88 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/hybrid\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>89 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>16.3 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>11.9 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>15.8 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>210 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/136903502\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">ZTF is an ongoing survey monitoring 15000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in the <em>g</em> and <em>r</em> bands. For the estimation of discovery rates, we assume that all candidates will be detected in the most effective filter, i.e. the <em>r</em> band. A 5\u03c3 limiting magnitude per pointing in this survey is 20.6 (Bellm et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). As a Pan-STARRS-based survey example, we consider a strategy which is alternative to ZTF. The sky coverage is only 20\u00a0per\u2009cent of that in ZTF, but in <em>griz</em> bands with the same cadence as ZTF. All lensed SNe detectable in this survey would be found in the <em>i</em> band for which the survey would reach a 5\u03c3 limiting magnitude of 20.6 per pointing. The potentially more effective <em>z</em> band would not improve detection rates due to its shallower depth of 20.2. Both ZTF and the Pan-STARRS survey operate in the regime of limiting magnitudes at which the only effective detection technique is the magnification method. Therefore, we omit the rates expected for the image multiplicity and hybrid techniques for them in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">LSST will cover about 20\u2009000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in 6 <em>ugrizy</em> bands every 2\u20133 weeks with a limiting magnitude of 24 (LSST Science Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Precise estimation of discovery rates relies on details of the observational strategy which is yet to be decided. However, reasonable estimates can be obtained based on the following reasoning. A typical redshift of strongly lensed SNe to be discovered by LSST is <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1. This means that the faintest SNe can be detected only within a time window of about 10\u00a0d (rest frame) around the peak of their light curve (20\u00a0d in the observer frame). In order to satisfy this condition, all detectable SNe should be at least 0.2 mag brighter at the peak than the actual limiting magnitudes of the survey which are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(24.5,\\, 24.2,\\, 23.6,\\, 22.8,\\, 22.0)$|</span> in the <em>grizy</em> bands (mean 5\u03c3 per pointing; based on LSST collaboration\u2019s simulations, baseline2018a run,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> which is the current official reference simulated survey). Then, the expected discovery rate can be found as the maximum rate found for all filters. Since LSST will observe down to limiting magnitudes at which the image multiplicity method becomes effective, we provide rate estimates for all three methods of finding lensed SN candidates. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> also shows the most effective filter (with the highest rate) for different SN types and detection methods.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pre-LSST surveys may find about five strongly lensed SNe per year, based solely on the magnification method. The most frequent type will be IIn, followed by Ia. Discovery rates will increase by nearly two orders of magnitude for LSST. It is also clear that the magnification method is expected to yield only about two\u00a0times more discoveries than the image multiplication method. However, both methods will detect lensed SNe at comparable rates when we assume that the measured flux in the magnification methods comes solely from the brightest image (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). Furthermore, keeping in mind that multiply imaged transients do not require follow-up observations confirming their lensing nature (in contrast to highly magnified transients which can be confused with superluminous SNe), we conclude that the image multiplicity method will be the most effective technique for finding lensed transients in LSST data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensed SNe discovered by LSST will be typically detected in the <em>i</em> band as a multiply imaged transient and in the <em>y</em> band (or the <em>z</em> band for type Ia and IIP) as a highly magnified transient (except for type IIn which will be discovered primarily in bluer filters). The difference in the effective discovery band can strengthen the complementarity of the two detection techniques. Considering a hybrid method of finding lensed SNe via image multiplicity in the <em>i</em> band and magnification in the <em>y</em> band (or <em>z</em> for Type Ia and IIP), we find that discovery rates in this approach are higher by 30\u201350\u00a0per\u2009cent than those based solely on magnification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Except for type IIP SNe, our discovery rates estimated for ZTF and LSST based on the magnification method agree fairly well with analogous predictions obtained by Goldstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). Adopting the same detection conditions and survey parameters for LSST, we also recover fairly closely the rates estimated by Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), with the total number of lensed Type Ia and core-collapse SNe to be discovered by LSST of 32 and 36. These rates are lower by a factor of &gt;10 than those listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and obtained by Goldstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). These differences can be fully accounted for to the stricter detection criteria adopted by Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), i.e. an effective limiting magnitude of 22.6 in the <em>i</em> band (in order to sample light curves at minimum depth of 0.7 mag around the peak) and an effective survey time of 2.5\u00a0yr (accounting for seasonal changes of the surveyed area), and do not signal discrepancies in the basic methodologies in the independent approaches to estimating detection rates. It is worth mentioning that more restrictive selection criteria than those proposed by Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) are required for obtaining high-quality measurements of gravitational time delays. In particular, a minimum precision of 5\u00a0per\u2009cent and an accuracy of 1\u00a0per\u2009cent in the time delay measurements (if based solely on LSST observations) would reduce the number of lensed type Ia SNe to about 1 per year (Huber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This rate can be increased by a factor of 2\u201316 by employing other instruments for follow-up observations.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903508 id=\"136903508\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Observed fractions of supernova types</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> shows predicted fractions of different types of SNe in representative samples of gravitationally lensed SNe expected in transient surveys with a range of limiting magnitudes between 19 and 26.</p>                        <a id=\"136903510\" scrollto-destination=\"136903510\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=DoTEbRgEvGC~vhsu9bfMCorwsXhTJGL59KXWDcXivTWp4SVbchAJNJ69374duux38ySfkWCXKVCONqapWIV7-b3qpNznr6gaIYlZIrvUV1UC5WhkIbGP1OG2tdCpX9aVRktcWNi8OOyOzLIykovuG0TiA~F7O2ina8pvyV8auDn0K86bbCIvJJgQc2SQEIF3~ZYggeX4EuKllC4BZcXnI3j6maqPcYHP90Tg7DltAA8Gy4vYXXpUIh5zr9x~aZanzJYnmEmCmNL~1JFyQqiBHPIdDvV50s6oQlPpJK9VB7XOPQOPhNrkY1a7Y75MqjiobsV1-bBvEckxe1ve7~krbQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fractions of different SN types in samples of gravitationally lensed SNe detected in transient surveys with limiting magnitude ilim in the i band. Gravitationally lensed SNe are detected via magnification (dashed curves) or using the hybrid method (solid curves).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903510/stz1516fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903510\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=LZaryl3SXcNUAeeRgRiMZi-vJTPBNsa8ADJOlC3gsVLJpLBstkD-UOcqYR~JmYL7Z9UmPXmnQGKWVxtse0RFcbF50A7aOkTnRJwcFw5mQMo~OZCVHJrahFmEyXepDsPqkkHh4Zd4TBXMAWKz~jFolg-koQrdFeCHNLAMeOaHWH9rwPduryZPnCqnt1C8PoU8i5cLnjpL8WnVwjXOS1Lf4AEKgf-zxf-KmMpa5pjQoPlrbS48O1L4b-N2FOSr62MjGl-pDetgZHNmvTdO5TRbd0k-yUG8F8gwsFgqlHwX65-EWBGO~KKfvC8GzcZ0ICoS1ikgr~j~8fGDwtdwxUgYqw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903510&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fractions of different SN types in samples of gravitationally lensed SNe detected in transient surveys with limiting magnitude <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band. Gravitationally lensed SNe are detected via magnification (dashed curves) or using the hybrid method (solid curves).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=DoTEbRgEvGC~vhsu9bfMCorwsXhTJGL59KXWDcXivTWp4SVbchAJNJ69374duux38ySfkWCXKVCONqapWIV7-b3qpNznr6gaIYlZIrvUV1UC5WhkIbGP1OG2tdCpX9aVRktcWNi8OOyOzLIykovuG0TiA~F7O2ina8pvyV8auDn0K86bbCIvJJgQc2SQEIF3~ZYggeX4EuKllC4BZcXnI3j6maqPcYHP90Tg7DltAA8Gy4vYXXpUIh5zr9x~aZanzJYnmEmCmNL~1JFyQqiBHPIdDvV50s6oQlPpJK9VB7XOPQOPhNrkY1a7Y75MqjiobsV1-bBvEckxe1ve7~krbQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fractions of different SN types in samples of gravitationally lensed SNe detected in transient surveys with limiting magnitude ilim in the i band. Gravitationally lensed SNe are detected via magnification (dashed curves) or using the hybrid method (solid curves).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903510/stz1516fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903510\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=LZaryl3SXcNUAeeRgRiMZi-vJTPBNsa8ADJOlC3gsVLJpLBstkD-UOcqYR~JmYL7Z9UmPXmnQGKWVxtse0RFcbF50A7aOkTnRJwcFw5mQMo~OZCVHJrahFmEyXepDsPqkkHh4Zd4TBXMAWKz~jFolg-koQrdFeCHNLAMeOaHWH9rwPduryZPnCqnt1C8PoU8i5cLnjpL8WnVwjXOS1Lf4AEKgf-zxf-KmMpa5pjQoPlrbS48O1L4b-N2FOSr62MjGl-pDetgZHNmvTdO5TRbd0k-yUG8F8gwsFgqlHwX65-EWBGO~KKfvC8GzcZ0ICoS1ikgr~j~8fGDwtdwxUgYqw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903510&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fractions of different SN types in samples of gravitationally lensed SNe detected in transient surveys with limiting magnitude <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band. Gravitationally lensed SNe are detected via magnification (dashed curves) or using the hybrid method (solid curves).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed fractions depend quite weakly on limiting magnitude. The most noticeable trend occurs for type IIP, IIL, and Ibc at large limiting magnitudes for the image multiplicity method. The highest fractions of these supernovae are expected for extremely shallow or deep surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Type Ia and IIn SNe clearly dominate detections, with fractions of about 30\u00a0per\u2009cent each. The prevalence of type IIn SNe becomes even stronger Ia when one includes detections in the <em>g</em> band, the most efficient filter for observing type IIn SNe. We emphasize that the high relative discovery rates of type IIn SNe rely quite strongly on the adopted spectral templates which in turn depend on the extinction correction performed in the analysis of the observational data used here (see Di Carlo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Nevertheless, the high predicted relative detection rates of lensed type IIn SNe is intriguing. The rates and luminosity distribution of type IIn supernovae at high redshift are quite uncertain, theoretically because of their wide range of possible progenitors, including very massive stars in the tail of the initial mass function (e.g. Gal-Yam\u00a0&amp; Leonard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Smith <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Th\u00f6ne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and observationally, because of their diverse photometric properties (e.g. Taddia et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Richardson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014b</a>; Cappellaro et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Fortunately, lensed type IIn SNe can readily be distinguished from other SNe due to their narrow (and hence high spectroscopic signal-to-noise ratio) Balmer emission lines. Hence, observations of lensed IIn could provide unique insights into their intrinsic properties at high redshift.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903514 id=\"136903514\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 Discovery space</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The detection methods considered in this study may also lead to differences in the phase space of lensing configurations. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> shows the distributions of basic lensing parameters of lensed type Ia SNe as a function of limiting <em>i</em>-band magnitude. The green contours shows 10-quantiles of the distributions expected for the hybrid method. The purple and orange curves show the median and a range containing 80\u00a0per\u2009cent of the cases for the magnification and image multiplicity techniques, respectively. We omit results for the image multiplication technique at limiting magnitudes lower than <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 21.5 where the method is far less competitive, with the potential discovery rate smaller than 10\u00a0per\u2009cent of that of the magnification technique. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> also shows the fractions of the different image configurations with two (doubles), three (cusps), and four images (quads).</p>                        <a id=\"136903516\" scrollto-destination=\"136903516\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=DXfePdM37P3eYwex9Y-qCATTrPGZWBXLgb8RJNJnxXDZa6ufprBJ9PSjsPh0XuO~QyQHlP8DtsxLi~Xy8pRxrArLFFvu9luGHot-KiOH0eZwf2vO9AWzPW9lCr3oAw36rMRZ8QdBQS7zBowOGMnuzCL96j~JSrqD-BmRnVZYi9Uw1RaKL3Js73WisLMRG2TFKsFrmjHGRzzC4NvqfLBZ1TRFwrIGy4cEz39FrOaBuRn38kTGaCwlFHHVY8qw3aV1cxFkZELBml7L2wTTC7SfPsUg40-CsANYMnmKjC55ZkDE19g5PdGJAtcnWarOcgpK1DGgPKd6opCT0srUioKfTA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Discovery space of gravitationally lensed type Ia SNe detected with different methods in a single-filter survey with depth ilim in the i band. The panels show distributions of supernova redshift zSN, lens redshift zlens, total magnification \u03bctotal, gravitational time delay averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394t\u3009 and image separation averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394\u03b8\u3009. The green contours show 10-quantiles of the distributions for supernova samples produced by the hybrid method. The purple and orange curves show the median and 80-per\u2009cent probability range of probability distributions for the magnification and image multiplicity methods, respectively. The results for the image multiplicity are shown only for detection rates larger than 10\u00a0per\u2009cent of the corresponding detection rates for the magnification method. The bottom right panel shows fractions of different lensing configurations with two images (doubles), three images (cusps), or four images (quads).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903516/stz1516fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903516\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=sjz9bsGm~EL2smAikIwx56q3ibyyeFyeAz4wmVAQXv5dn4E92Jg81jqaxNOM5ZM7AE51-l5AXAACqHZEh5Rq4FpowEYMjnyWlC3O7uuge8JZ0-S96zGWdtDA97pojBRl1qSFQMZhx6R6A6HYW0t7P9uGgavxZYXLWbxesRJPhudllH5wvP5Dq-bz3QfonfPyVz8jt3mpSlKDXYoTQu2iF6QfQ--2t3syAIe8tMKFlRM5lJYjm-ytOD7VfvmqSB~38-mSHT0Ik3JZZJUXkQROefXk0x9QxNA1lLpoGgPfydWM9TcUrHT48cl66Nt0wVotRifWT~iTa9sRRU9SMwedhQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903516&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Discovery space of gravitationally lensed type Ia SNe detected with different methods in a single-filter survey with depth <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band.
