(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>), and Cappellaro, Evans\u00a0&amp; Turatto <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">(1999</a>).</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The rate of core-collapse SNe is directly proportional to the star formation history \u03c8(<em>z</em>): <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ12\" content-id=\"equ12\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nn_{\\rm SNCC}(z)=k_{\\rm CC}\\psi (z), \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(12)</span></div>where <em>k</em><sub>CC</sub> is the number of stars that explode as SNe per unit mass. For our study, we adopt <em>k</em><sub>CC</sub>\u00a0= 0.0068M<sub>\u2299</sub><sup>\u22121</sup> expected for a mass range of SN progenitors (8\u2009,\u200940\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>) and a Salpeter initial mass function. Since the same initial function was consistently assumed in the derivation of the star formation rate from observations, the predicted rate of core-collapse SNe is practically independent of the initial mass function (Madau\u00a0&amp; Dickinson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The resulting core-collapse SN rate is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We calculate light curves and <em>K</em>-corrections of simulated type Ia SNe (normal branch) using a time-series of spectral templates computed by Nugent, Kim\u00a0&amp; Perlmutter (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). Following Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we assume that the absolute magnitude is normally distributed with a mean of \u221219.3 in the <em>B</em> band and a scatter of 0.2. We also check the impact of using a more realistic distribution with three\u00a0times longer Gaussian tail at low luminosities accounting for faint supernovae in volume-limited samples (see e.g. Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). For core-collapse SNe, we consider types Ib/c, IIP, IIL, and IIn, assuming that their relative contributions to the total number density of core-collapse SNe are independent of redshift and constrained by low-redshift observations resulting in 16, 49, 9, and 5\u00a0per\u2009cent respectively for Ib/c, IIP, IIL, and IIn (Li et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Graur et\u00a0al. 2017). We realize light curves of the four SN subclasses using spectral templates from a compilation which is an extension of the work by Nugent et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>),<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> based primarily on data from Levan et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>) for type Ibc, Di Carlo et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) for IIn, and Gilliland, Nugent\u00a0&amp; Phillips (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) for the remaining two types. We approximate the distribution of absolute magnitudes in the <em>B</em> band by Gaussians with mean and scatter of \u221217.50 and 1.0 for type Ib/c, \u221216.70 and 1.0 for type IIP, \u221217.9 and 0.90 for type IIL, \u221218.5 and 1.0 (after discarding two outliers with <em>M</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0= \u221215.1, \u221222.2) for IIn (Richardson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014a</a>, for <em>h</em>\u00a0= 0.73). The assumed luminosity functions for all classes of SNe are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We note that the borderline between different classes may not be entirely clear cut. For example, there may be a continuous transition between type IIP and type IIL SNe (e.g. Anderson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). In this sense, these types can be seen as being representative for the fainter and more luminous ends of the type II SN population.</p>                        <a id=\"136903468\" scrollto-destination=\"136903468\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=N1pNGwu52iuhoIZUZL-d5Fi8lPoPDSiiQTAkjwREGFjWSKDX72qB1IyZndWTGOSnpztVfvHBCLkUhu8uguB2KRnZv8zrKGV2s4D~AEOZbku1cbIqETabjUN2u1KON6NfC7Hn0JrrMWa6mOqjSQjZGJOr7yeE7X88otsIKFv81UE1dEMF5QERC0zyYV9t4LwqPLAFqB5YFuz4GXsvbKzeV-Zql2BPa1y7XeVvXV5COQOzgZpIP~KU5ocw6gpFU4kVxye~qqHnPlWQHqCkss839ndZ533DRdaMER52usmy0GYBd~Sq-Ycq4~-sZH1nCGOw4calzYANV8eefmtdVePeDQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of absolute luminosities in the B band of the different types of SNe considered in our study. Normalizations of the distributions are proportional to the local volumetric rates of the correposnding SN classes. The green dashed curve shows an alternative model for type Ia SNe with with a tail accounting for low-luminosity SNe.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903468/stz1516fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903468\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=W792qvGFrA1vLRCeThQUwuL5ByMtvFzO6njXz0oYKzUAuXQWn79GKY9-Cu4fLwRI8hr1edjT0pJbDEUkYMbaZySIlCEHm5r~alYowrKBHzvdVUoM3cgKd0eVJ4wl053RYNl38Lx-Q1gbW77X8Hz0NaDqeDsoNiyJKhPD00QQu~~XL4s0lj2tpCN7rtmjWbfxshKWPf9dc~5SXCkAfj6OU9RyTn4nml9ye4i8V87IPYN1f~E0Z9uYyw8TFI727Wne1Kg6Z~bkXLnYbBe6d-nkh~yg7Irwdx~Qa44IguRCSl9Oto4y9HwlVZBtBGvE40l3ZdUnVSVjlQYPXAOO-hbgJw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903468&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of absolute luminosities in the <em>B</em> band of the different types of SNe considered in our study. Normalizations of the distributions are proportional to the local volumetric rates of the correposnding SN classes. The green dashed curve shows an alternative model for type Ia SNe with with a tail accounting for low-luminosity SNe.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=N1pNGwu52iuhoIZUZL-d5Fi8lPoPDSiiQTAkjwREGFjWSKDX72qB1IyZndWTGOSnpztVfvHBCLkUhu8uguB2KRnZv8zrKGV2s4D~AEOZbku1cbIqETabjUN2u1KON6NfC7Hn0JrrMWa6mOqjSQjZGJOr7yeE7X88otsIKFv81UE1dEMF5QERC0zyYV9t4LwqPLAFqB5YFuz4GXsvbKzeV-Zql2BPa1y7XeVvXV5COQOzgZpIP~KU5ocw6gpFU4kVxye~qqHnPlWQHqCkss839ndZ533DRdaMER52usmy0GYBd~Sq-Ycq4~-sZH1nCGOw4calzYANV8eefmtdVePeDQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of absolute luminosities in the B band of the different types of SNe considered in our study. Normalizations of the distributions are proportional to the local volumetric rates of the correposnding SN classes. The green dashed curve shows an alternative model for type Ia SNe with with a tail accounting for low-luminosity SNe.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903468/stz1516fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903468\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=W792qvGFrA1vLRCeThQUwuL5ByMtvFzO6njXz0oYKzUAuXQWn79GKY9-Cu4fLwRI8hr1edjT0pJbDEUkYMbaZySIlCEHm5r~alYowrKBHzvdVUoM3cgKd0eVJ4wl053RYNl38Lx-Q1gbW77X8Hz0NaDqeDsoNiyJKhPD00QQu~~XL4s0lj2tpCN7rtmjWbfxshKWPf9dc~5SXCkAfj6OU9RyTn4nml9ye4i8V87IPYN1f~E0Z9uYyw8TFI727Wne1Kg6Z~bkXLnYbBe6d-nkh~yg7Irwdx~Qa44IguRCSl9Oto4y9HwlVZBtBGvE40l3ZdUnVSVjlQYPXAOO-hbgJw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903468&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of absolute luminosities in the <em>B</em> band of the different types of SNe considered in our study. Normalizations of the distributions are proportional to the local volumetric rates of the correposnding SN classes. The green dashed curve shows an alternative model for type Ia SNe with with a tail accounting for low-luminosity SNe.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903469 id=\"136903469\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Computation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">First, we generate a random sample of lens galaxies at redshifts <em>z</em> &lt; 1.2. We find that it is sufficient to realize 10<sup>5</sup> lens galaxies and then rescale the final counts of strongly lensed SNe according to the actual number of lens galaxies contained in the assumed comoving volume. Then, we populate the observational cone up to redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3 with SNe. In order to reduce shot noise, we artificially increase the SNe rate by a factor of 5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>5</sup>. The actual detection rate is then retrieved by scaling down the counts by the same factor. In order to save computational time (driven primarily by lensing computations), we discard all supernovae at angular distances larger than 4\u03b8<sub>E</sub>. These SNe are typically too far from the lenses to be multiply imaged or strongly magnified. Our choice of a maximum redshift for the lenses and the SNe allows us to determine detection rates of strongly lensed SNe for limiting magnitudes up to 26, which is around 2 mag deeper than the envisaged depth for the LSST.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For every lens\u2013supernova pair we calculate all basic lensing properties, i.e. image multiplicity, magnifications, positions of the images, and time delays. The lensing equations are solved numerically using the publicly available code for lensing calculations, <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). When calculating time-dependent apparent magnitudes, we take into account both the effects of magnification and time delay determined for every image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Once the complete Monte Carlo sample of strongly lensed SNe is computed, we can employ different detection criteria and thus determine the number of detectable lensed SNe as a function of survey depth in several different bands. This part of the calculations is independent of the assumed cosmological model and volumetric SN rates; therefore, it can be repeated for different detection criteria using the same pre-computed Monte Carlo sample of strongly lensed SNe and the corresponding lensing properties. The SN yields are computed for observations in five SDSS/LSST filters: <em>g, r, i, z</em>, and <em>y</em>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903473 id=\"136903473\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 RESULTS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903474 id=\"136903474\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Type Ia supernovae</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> compares detection rates for strongly lensed type Ia SNe expected for the three methods with the base choice of free parameters, as outlined in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. Our results demonstrate that the method based on detecting highly magnified SNe surpasses the image multiplicity technique for relatively shallow surveys with limiting magnitudes \u2272 22. In particular, for a survey with a 21 mag depth, the magnification method is expected to find \u223c20\u00a0times more strongly lensed SNe than the image multiplicity method. Due to the stronger dependence on the limiting magnitude for the image multiplicity method, this ratio becomes larger for even shallower surveys, with a threefold change per magnitude in the <em>i</em> band.</p>                        <a id=\"136903476\" scrollto-destination=\"136903476\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=v5ZM9BaTaZ47Gsw3L2H6keFnwfxSC-acagmqjCquILiqgk-PO0Iry868YRuOvVM~5DShY3PSRbYJSIGcCguJ0lXQbxou9qmZTiDebzRuRahh8KAzCHigwf9YfhbHlTn6kRCqRFmRgp~l2OXf9dKZXG4VXfaK~ZcLTE54Iwkst4DpVYFrEuCT95ncz6tz5AEmps6QmdBliwBWlA8EsFTQmQEgAjTPem9ADFeDLRPYHdlctu7g9tK-BO8nhDY-MD4jF3hSlPIV8gAENVWDRbI3jxZaZ9ecDnXhzMSyTWPYPcc41B7PYb5xii8GGUhhzNpYlsrxTRAHq8Xs8GGRwDqDcA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Detection rates of strongly lensed type Ia SNe as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SNe yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. The shaded band indicates the range of detection rates given by the extent to which flux is integrated over the SN images, with the upper and lower limits corresponding to the total measured flux from all images (upper limit) or solely from the brightest image (lower limit).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903476/stz1516fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903476\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=Cvn0t13fCO1cQlb16s2EMfRzNjIiFB~lWkTgGumbtE7axDyuwZdr79Q-sn4NlzkdnbV8V7gLFxFi-jpuwWJyA2JLqb8kojuT8qtAMYAVBiiVwMVx--iJEy8yqrTNasskHDI-0b-TNoX3ToffBJvhaLVh-GVKTWgUOdSMvry0qI0UgicOh1F8DszsJHXLQOFei3~0Hlqatn6U09tqIYIGyJjhQYmuFrsoQAh~0wxICXWa77fYFrwnQxCqFJ6gq8UjWLRxy6dCB0XG~GCT24bwCKN8Sh5rRMfA2Q3wG6JCcUu1BkdVvyEsxtNbSGd4~SSZd3zqOON7Ua-MAE3tP~qp~A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903476&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detection rates of strongly lensed type Ia SNe as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SNe yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. The shaded band indicates the range of detection rates given by the extent to which flux is integrated over the SN images, with the upper and lower limits corresponding to the total measured flux from all images (upper limit) or solely from the brightest image (lower limit).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=v5ZM9BaTaZ47Gsw3L2H6keFnwfxSC-acagmqjCquILiqgk-PO0Iry868YRuOvVM~5DShY3PSRbYJSIGcCguJ0lXQbxou9qmZTiDebzRuRahh8KAzCHigwf9YfhbHlTn6kRCqRFmRgp~l2OXf9dKZXG4VXfaK~ZcLTE54Iwkst4DpVYFrEuCT95ncz6tz5AEmps6QmdBliwBWlA8EsFTQmQEgAjTPem9ADFeDLRPYHdlctu7g9tK-BO8nhDY-MD4jF3hSlPIV8gAENVWDRbI3jxZaZ9ecDnXhzMSyTWPYPcc41B7PYb5xii8GGUhhzNpYlsrxTRAHq8Xs8GGRwDqDcA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Detection rates of strongly lensed type Ia SNe as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SNe yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. The shaded band indicates the range of detection rates given by the extent to which flux is integrated over the SN images, with the upper and lower limits corresponding to the total measured flux from all images (upper limit) or solely from the brightest image (lower limit).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903476/stz1516fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903476\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=Cvn0t13fCO1cQlb16s2EMfRzNjIiFB~lWkTgGumbtE7axDyuwZdr79Q-sn4NlzkdnbV8V7gLFxFi-jpuwWJyA2JLqb8kojuT8qtAMYAVBiiVwMVx--iJEy8yqrTNasskHDI-0b-TNoX3ToffBJvhaLVh-GVKTWgUOdSMvry0qI0UgicOh1F8DszsJHXLQOFei3~0Hlqatn6U09tqIYIGyJjhQYmuFrsoQAh~0wxICXWa77fYFrwnQxCqFJ6gq8UjWLRxy6dCB0XG~GCT24bwCKN8Sh5rRMfA2Q3wG6JCcUu1BkdVvyEsxtNbSGd4~SSZd3zqOON7Ua-MAE3tP~qp~A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903476&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detection rates of strongly lensed type Ia SNe as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SNe yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. The shaded band indicates the range of detection rates given by the extent to which flux is integrated over the SN images, with the upper and lower limits corresponding to the total measured flux from all images (upper limit) or solely from the brightest image (lower limit).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For limiting magnitudes \u2273 23, increasing survey depth does not improve the performance of the magnification method, but it appreciably increases the rates for the other method. For deep surveys like the LSST, detecting multiple images appears to become a more powerful means for finding lensed type Ia SNe than gravitational magnification. The image multiplicity method is expected to yield about twice as many detections as the magnification method at a limiting magnitude of 24. The difference between the two methods becomes even more prominent for deeper surveys: the rates expected for the image multiplicity method increase exponentially with limiting magnitudes in a range between 24 and 26, whereas the rates from the magnification method become constant.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Both methods are expected to find comparable numbers of lensed type Ia SNe at limiting magnitudes between 23.0 in the <em>g</em> band to 23.8 in the <em>y</em> band. The lensed SN samples returned by the two methods happen to be only weakly overlapping; therefore, combining both detection criteria is expected to increase the yields, especially at intermediate limiting magnitudes. This is demonstrated by the solid curves which show detection rates for the hybrid method which identifies strongly lensed SNe either as highly magnified or multiply imaged transients. The hybrid method maximizes SN yields at all limiting magnitudes. Unsurprisingly, it follows closely the rates from the magnification method at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2272 21 and the image multiplicity technique at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2273 24.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The performance of the magnification method depends on the choice of the number of images that contribute to the total flux in the observations. The red band in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> shows the expected range of the rates modulated by this effect. The upper limit corresponds to detections based on flux integrated over all images, whereas the lower limit is expected for detections based on flux solely from the brightest image. The average ratio between the upper and lower limits is 2, with a very weak dependence on survey depth and filters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The apparent differences between detection rates from the two main methods reflect the fact that gravitational magnification and image multiplicity are not equally prominent features of strong lensing at different depths. The relatively poor performances of the magnification method for deep surveys (<em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &gt; 23) or the image multiplicity method for shallower surveys (<em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &lt; 23) cannot be appreciably improved by modifying the criteria for selecting the candidates. We demonstrate these intrinsic limitations in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, where we show supernova yields for different choices of the free parameters defining the detection criteria in the two methods. Reducing the magnitude gap \u0394<em>m</em> in the magnification method results naturally in a higher detection rate. However, the improvement is limited solely to magnitudes \u2273 22 where the method is clearly outperformed by the image multiplicity technique. Furthermore, this inevitably leads to a higher false positive detection rates due to intrinsically bright type Ia SNe.</p>                        <a id=\"136903481\" scrollto-destination=\"136903481\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=S4eeX1A4oYFjhNn9XFCljxvQuDO4MWWebAmeffn3a8m9ebcEsNSrtlmgLSiSIdyv1di1c4yKBx~U-0OmMWy63yenJLD7RPh5lR3tSuzTLXktjTsktF5eo8vWLb4z-hn8VUQWe3Rga70QjfL6NvwYggSGC1Y~BuLkJALAsPkaeaQTxbpKunstrcExYIG01EhlGHo~V2~tPXESXoFF2r8nX28VBIp7Fu3yimBsaPM~Wr7lrjoaOoxaTEQ81rBFCOnnb0AbRvvue4YEiyb~Afy8BQnU61V0R7GPkOg6WiXWcFlhm6APDnkOhOlqDsgINYhipaq9TOHVG2gsAtiMluQp-Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sensitivity of detecting lensed type Ia SN in the z band to parameters and conditions defining detection criteria of the two methods based on selecting highly magnified (red curves) or multiply imaged supernovae (green curves). The parameter \u0394m is a minimum enhancement of the apparent brightness due to lensing magnification relative to the mean magnitude of type Ia SNe expected in the apparent host (lens) galaxy (\u0394m\u00a0= \u22120.7 for the base model). For the image multiplicity method, discovery rates depend on the minimum number of detectable images. The solid and dashed curves compare the two cases for which at least three (base model) or two images are detectable for quads and cusps. The red dashed\u2013dotted curves shows the impact of accounting for the possible low-luminosity tail in the luminosity function dnSNIa/dMB of type Ia SNe (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a02) on the expected discovery rates.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903481/stz1516fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903481\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=IucYubcej5fv~xyaBGNnDY-6vbf5iDwmWYlDe95WgSqBN7ATPMsOUzMZNmLbINTZDWUSWOD2uw5UJj~~ofJxy~KUmp-lThclKHgJ1saSdFGyAUezGCZf0cm0piFb4UoQRFY~r7oqR9nE0UYUiMwFabQpiVBVn2xg~teJHPAfz3AMjMCb3pGu6iGk8ha5fsK1w4XYs~x3CkkKOtNnSs4690fHlo4HaUB6Y~LsjvBWbpp8vr3v0x9LsbIWW~72Cz1gEcMiRhGcSKak6OUSsWe16bj81C8JfE0iYGm~e5PQaFmOf7fboeSd1Zb1kShnc4s~j75JvRMzecRTsmjW4uwFFw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903481&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sensitivity of detecting lensed type Ia SN in the <em>z</em> band to parameters and conditions defining detection criteria of the two methods based on selecting highly magnified (red curves) or multiply imaged supernovae (green curves). The parameter \u0394<em>m</em> is a minimum enhancement of the apparent brightness due to lensing magnification relative to the mean magnitude of type Ia SNe expected in the apparent host (lens) galaxy (\u0394<em>m</em>\u00a0= \u22120.7 for the base model). For the image multiplicity method, discovery rates depend on the minimum number of detectable images. The solid and dashed curves compare the two cases for which at least three (base model) or two images are detectable for quads and cusps. The red dashed\u2013dotted curves shows the impact of accounting for the possible low-luminosity tail in the luminosity function d<em>n</em><sub>SNIa</sub>/d<em>M</em><sub>B</sub> of type Ia SNe (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) on the expected discovery rates.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=S4eeX1A4oYFjhNn9XFCljxvQuDO4MWWebAmeffn3a8m9ebcEsNSrtlmgLSiSIdyv1di1c4yKBx~U-0OmMWy63yenJLD7RPh5lR3tSuzTLXktjTsktF5eo8vWLb4z-hn8VUQWe3Rga70QjfL6NvwYggSGC1Y~BuLkJALAsPkaeaQTxbpKunstrcExYIG01EhlGHo~V2~tPXESXoFF2r8nX28VBIp7Fu3yimBsaPM~Wr7lrjoaOoxaTEQ81rBFCOnnb0AbRvvue4YEiyb~Afy8BQnU61V0R7GPkOg6WiXWcFlhm6APDnkOhOlqDsgINYhipaq9TOHVG2gsAtiMluQp-Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sensitivity of detecting lensed type Ia SN in the z band to parameters and conditions defining detection criteria of the two methods based on selecting highly magnified (red curves) or multiply imaged supernovae (green curves). The parameter \u0394m is a minimum enhancement of the apparent brightness due to lensing magnification relative to the mean magnitude of type Ia SNe expected in the apparent host (lens) galaxy (\u0394m\u00a0= \u22120.7 for the base model). For the image multiplicity method, discovery rates depend on the minimum number of detectable images. The solid and dashed curves compare the two cases for which at least three (base model) or two images are detectable for quads and cusps. The red dashed\u2013dotted curves shows the impact of accounting for the possible low-luminosity tail in the luminosity function dnSNIa/dMB of type Ia SNe (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a02) on the expected discovery rates.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903481/stz1516fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903481\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=IucYubcej5fv~xyaBGNnDY-6vbf5iDwmWYlDe95WgSqBN7ATPMsOUzMZNmLbINTZDWUSWOD2uw5UJj~~ofJxy~KUmp-lThclKHgJ1saSdFGyAUezGCZf0cm0piFb4UoQRFY~r7oqR9nE0UYUiMwFabQpiVBVn2xg~teJHPAfz3AMjMCb3pGu6iGk8ha5fsK1w4XYs~x3CkkKOtNnSs4690fHlo4HaUB6Y~LsjvBWbpp8vr3v0x9LsbIWW~72Cz1gEcMiRhGcSKak6OUSsWe16bj81C8JfE0iYGm~e5PQaFmOf7fboeSd1Zb1kShnc4s~j75JvRMzecRTsmjW4uwFFw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903481&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sensitivity of detecting lensed type Ia SN in the <em>z</em> band to parameters and conditions defining detection criteria of the two methods based on selecting highly magnified (red curves) or multiply imaged supernovae (green curves). The parameter \u0394<em>m</em> is a minimum enhancement of the apparent brightness due to lensing magnification relative to the mean magnitude of type Ia SNe expected in the apparent host (lens) galaxy (\u0394<em>m</em>\u00a0= \u22120.7 for the base model). For the image multiplicity method, discovery rates depend on the minimum number of detectable images. The solid and dashed curves compare the two cases for which at least three (base model) or two images are detectable for quads and cusps. The red dashed\u2013dotted curves shows the impact of accounting for the possible low-luminosity tail in the luminosity function d<em>n</em><sub>SNIa</sub>/d<em>M</em><sub>B</sub> of type Ia SNe (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) on the expected discovery rates.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relaxing the selection criteria for the image multiplicity method by including all systems with at least two detectable images (for all images configurations) improves the SN yields only at small limiting magnitudes, e.g. by a factor of 4 at <em>z</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2248 21 (see the green dashed curve in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). The resulting detection rates, however, are still smaller than those of the magnification method. Since the selection criterion cannot be relaxed even further, this case sets an upper limit for the expected detection rates based on image multiplicity. Finally, we find that changing the range of the maximum image separation does not appreciably modify the predictions for the lensed supernova yields.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A strong limitation of the magnification method is reflected by a plateau at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2273 22.5 which signifies that the method does not benefit from increasing survey depth. This feature is an unavoidable drawback of the method and it cannot be removed by simply adjusting \u0394<em>m</em> (subject to a reasonable condition \u0394<em>m</em> &lt; 0). It is primarily caused by the fact that high-redshift lenses and SNe require extremely large, and therefore improbable, magnifications in order to fall within a range of detectable fluxes. We illustrate this in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> which compares selections of lensed SN candidates in shallow (<em>i</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 21) and deep (<em>i</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 25) surveys. Faint, high-redshift SNe are not sufficiently magnified in order to be selected by the magnification method. Most of them happen to be fainter than a fiducial reference type Ia SN with absolute luminosity <em>M</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0= \u221220 that would be observed in the apparent host galaxy (actual lens galaxy). On the other hand, faint SNe from deep surveys appear to exhibit relatively brighter secondary images than those from shallow surveys. This makes the image multiplicity method more effective in selecting lensed SN candidates in deep surveys at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> \u2273 23.5.</p>                        <a id=\"136903484\" scrollto-destination=\"136903484\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=sQIQCfhO5byD2atl0F8lSVCxZtLOgbun7Gn7WhFfy2OmYB-cLuNGzyB3--~sD8IgKuzVKz0s-k0ycHuNWdgK~xDnoiN3WRpLa7Fc2CyotMKHBdz9YtKFxaT377UtkGFSQA17fEGZfs6dgrQZ17lT4th026irfHuCQNJGBTKZCIC0HmMgtwzHCwQ02P6FO26n2rE4JMdQdQfO5BQ1LNi-oWwkl1eC7klyljkXZrPxGi88z4TiltqhkXf3GB3UnQQO11mMded1efjLrxwd0lwMzEVTy5Jcoow6~qY1J~aSJR7MAC7SlZr7rpObXNfsmVqnc2tzABitdEq~dkGw7ZzA9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Selection of lensed SN candidates (using type Ia as an example) by means of finding highly magnified transients, i.e. brighter than a fiducial type Ia SNe observable in the apparent host (actual lens) galaxy (see the red arrow and the indicated shaded region), or detecting the second brightest image (see the blue arrow arrow and the indicated shaded region). The two contours show the distribution of all observable lensed SNe in two surveys with depths of 21 and 25 in the i band. The majority of bright, low-redshift SNe appear to be highly magnified, but featuring the secondary image beyond detection limits (purple contours). They can be found using primarily the magnification method. On the other hand, the majority of faint, high-redshift lensed SNe from a deep survey (green contours) are not sufficiently magnified to be detected as peculiarly bright supernovae, but they exhibit detectable second brightest images. These lensed SNe can be effectively found as doubly imaged transients.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903484/stz1516fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903484\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=GXK8SFzXFOZ2QauvdYKVM6XsPjZ-1ixEFcHa15C7bRvk9BefKTrfAgUonN9f~WAYbSpfmFF9O-BBpygfm3n0WEt6kKQX2ghjB-jKwMPr7RgKid7GVk71kvivN8GLCGwkFFsdQruKCTPKdJsCr-5hX1idjuE3el~7-25KCo6jaU6hDNmj0E3j5tM6g0AjjlVrI48NYBTTU7gyDaBqnPUDDljt1zj3hJ-MWURcXhB3Tm7E1aU-t9LqcMi7nJsD6H0XSrcpzAY6NbZuokYaPYP21ZB7noAGh9qPtSdhombsjbl0C5b-HmtxBhix8CaZUNazTRre1ostEl2xi1ssVEIWgg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903484&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Selection of lensed SN candidates (using type Ia as an example) by means of finding highly magnified transients, i.e. brighter than a fiducial type Ia SNe observable in the apparent host (actual lens) galaxy (see the red arrow and the indicated shaded region), or detecting the second brightest image (see the blue arrow arrow and the indicated shaded region). The two contours show the distribution of all observable lensed SNe in two surveys with depths of 21 and 25 in the <em>i</em> band. The majority of bright, low-redshift SNe appear to be highly magnified, but featuring the secondary image beyond detection limits (purple contours). They can be found using primarily the magnification method. On the other hand, the majority of faint, high-redshift lensed SNe from a deep survey (green contours) are not sufficiently magnified to be detected as peculiarly bright supernovae, but they exhibit detectable second brightest images. These lensed SNe can be effectively found as doubly imaged transients.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=sQIQCfhO5byD2atl0F8lSVCxZtLOgbun7Gn7WhFfy2OmYB-cLuNGzyB3--~sD8IgKuzVKz0s-k0ycHuNWdgK~xDnoiN3WRpLa7Fc2CyotMKHBdz9YtKFxaT377UtkGFSQA17fEGZfs6dgrQZ17lT4th026irfHuCQNJGBTKZCIC0HmMgtwzHCwQ02P6FO26n2rE4JMdQdQfO5BQ1LNi-oWwkl1eC7klyljkXZrPxGi88z4TiltqhkXf3GB3UnQQO11mMded1efjLrxwd0lwMzEVTy5Jcoow6~qY1J~aSJR7MAC7SlZr7rpObXNfsmVqnc2tzABitdEq~dkGw7ZzA9w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Selection of lensed SN candidates (using type Ia as an example) by means of finding highly magnified transients, i.e. brighter than a fiducial type Ia SNe observable in the apparent host (actual lens) galaxy (see the red arrow and the indicated shaded region), or detecting the second brightest image (see the blue arrow arrow and the indicated shaded region). The two contours show the distribution of all observable lensed SNe in two surveys with depths of 21 and 25 in the i band. The majority of bright, low-redshift SNe appear to be highly magnified, but featuring the secondary image beyond detection limits (purple contours). They can be found using primarily the magnification method. On the other hand, the majority of faint, high-redshift lensed SNe from a deep survey (green contours) are not sufficiently magnified to be detected as peculiarly bright supernovae, but they exhibit detectable second brightest images. These lensed SNe can be effectively found as doubly imaged transients.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903484/stz1516fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903484\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=GXK8SFzXFOZ2QauvdYKVM6XsPjZ-1ixEFcHa15C7bRvk9BefKTrfAgUonN9f~WAYbSpfmFF9O-BBpygfm3n0WEt6kKQX2ghjB-jKwMPr7RgKid7GVk71kvivN8GLCGwkFFsdQruKCTPKdJsCr-5hX1idjuE3el~7-25KCo6jaU6hDNmj0E3j5tM6g0AjjlVrI48NYBTTU7gyDaBqnPUDDljt1zj3hJ-MWURcXhB3Tm7E1aU-t9LqcMi7nJsD6H0XSrcpzAY6NbZuokYaPYP21ZB7noAGh9qPtSdhombsjbl0C5b-HmtxBhix8CaZUNazTRre1ostEl2xi1ssVEIWgg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903484&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Selection of lensed SN candidates (using type Ia as an example) by means of finding highly magnified transients, i.e. brighter than a fiducial type Ia SNe observable in the apparent host (actual lens) galaxy (see the red arrow and the indicated shaded region), or detecting the second brightest image (see the blue arrow arrow and the indicated shaded region). The two contours show the distribution of all observable lensed SNe in two surveys with depths of 21 and 25 in the <em>i</em> band. The majority of bright, low-redshift SNe appear to be highly magnified, but featuring the secondary image beyond detection limits (purple contours). They can be found using primarily the magnification method. On the other hand, the majority of faint, high-redshift lensed SNe from a deep survey (green contours) are not sufficiently magnified to be detected as peculiarly bright supernovae, but they exhibit detectable second brightest images. These lensed SNe can be effectively found as doubly imaged transients.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to show more quantitatively the differences between the magnification and image multiplicity methods of selecting lensed SNe candidates, we calculate the completeness of lensed SN searches as a function of survey depth (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). We define the 100\u00a0per\u2009cent complete reference sample as consisting of all observable/detectable lensed type Ia SNe, i.e. all multiply imaged type Ia SNe that are brighter than <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> at the peak of their light curves in at least one of the five bands, where apparent magnitudes are computed by integrating flux over all images. The figure shows that the magnification method maximizes its completeness for shallow surveys, with completeness reaching 80\u00a0per\u2009cent at \u2272 21.5 mag in the <em>z</em> or <em>y</em> band, and then it degrades at large survey depths. An inverse trend characterizes the completeness of the image multiplicity method which becomes more complete with increasing survey depth, reaching about 40\u00a0per\u2009cent at 25 mag in the <em>y</em> or <em>z</em> bands. The solid curves show the completeness of the hybrid method. It is evident that combining the magnification and the image multiplicity detection criteria improves the completeness at limiting magnitudes characteristic for the LSST, i.e. 22 &lt; <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &lt; 24. In particular, the hybrid method boosts the completeness by about 50\u00a0per\u2009cent in the <em>y</em> band relative to lensed SN searches based solely on the magnification or image multiplicity criterion. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> demonstrates also a difference between the magnification and image multiplicity methods in terms of redshift completeness. While the magnification technique can never be more complete than 20\u00a0per\u2009cent at all redshifts, the image multiplicity method attains an 80\u201390\u00a0per\u2009cent completeness up to a maximum redshift set by the survey depth.</p>                        <a id=\"136903486\" scrollto-destination=\"136903486\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=4jjO1R5gWuTgiHRAKn~2ncoZh7CRFptA5wXhqtIjYCEzdaI~Ox00IaempsPujtb-Doff3opc9vUYdBETyltnNXJJnoXl-KHRBrbiNkOSdXuu-bA1-icLlXaJAXpUynR4yXpbE8kgTKUA-1lAMYFApjz92NGPmJzcAf~OshdbxknR1Z5t8BoQKBGOiabbInUwYFGFBwisXUSHAegxX-Nxb8vUlqSqsHjvA0wVMFCuS2Ivz0gtQWNfB-ficc5DN6uNqnzNoVe8V6MJnT7xl7lw5B1VA-fBrJTbQ3FXqLek3llW2EXHcZ3jg9tn7RpoHJT3fHTRuLrTja4KHG1-rqtPvw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Completeness of lensed SN candidates found with three different methods, as a function of survey depth in five different bands. The vertical grey bands indicate the depths of ZTF and LSST. The method based on detecting highly magnified supernovae reaches an \u223c80\u00a0per\u2009cent completeness in the z and y bands at Xlim &lt; 21. The completeness of lensed SNe search by means of detecting image multiplicity increases with survey depth. The method becomes more complete than that based on magnification for surveys with depths comparable to or larger than the LSST.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903486/stz1516fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903486\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=PUGf36XJSpQAjOJWK8YzEMJd9-2IwangooCsbk~AXXo~VW9scaDZMrSY0cgTXWXkKoe2vUs6XSXjN3OMzjgmQ4UFVceYq40CG6fDjpnnkspvc1M2OWwpZDXzbdbFKi-28RpCImKtiHV8oKiiVfFUr1cgnzxWrzRD42UgZlOE4-Og3ujOTE-skvnFb6G2S4g6eTuvoD1TNgr02poh92uJGKWYnmUI2JLXq9WILXCavNxolwlSzCIBxAHt3dlU-fmEjUuXwlKryapqoSQNDTfcVJseYwUijeDn1LEk6UuC9WFY-1-T86ZelzLWMWwXFdAmPZxj3B68SI7TCBcNIXhYPQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903486&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Completeness of lensed SN candidates found with three different methods, as a function of survey depth in five different bands. The vertical grey bands indicate the depths of ZTF and LSST. The method based on detecting highly magnified supernovae reaches an \u223c80\u00a0per\u2009cent completeness in the <em>z</em> and <em>y</em> bands at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &lt; 21. The completeness of lensed SNe search by means of detecting image multiplicity increases with survey depth. The method becomes more complete than that based on magnification for surveys with depths comparable to or larger than the LSST.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=4jjO1R5gWuTgiHRAKn~2ncoZh7CRFptA5wXhqtIjYCEzdaI~Ox00IaempsPujtb-Doff3opc9vUYdBETyltnNXJJnoXl-KHRBrbiNkOSdXuu-bA1-icLlXaJAXpUynR4yXpbE8kgTKUA-1lAMYFApjz92NGPmJzcAf~OshdbxknR1Z5t8BoQKBGOiabbInUwYFGFBwisXUSHAegxX-Nxb8vUlqSqsHjvA0wVMFCuS2Ivz0gtQWNfB-ficc5DN6uNqnzNoVe8V6MJnT7xl7lw5B1VA-fBrJTbQ3FXqLek3llW2EXHcZ3jg9tn7RpoHJT3fHTRuLrTja4KHG1-rqtPvw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Completeness of lensed SN candidates found with three different methods, as a function of survey depth in five different bands. The vertical grey bands indicate the depths of ZTF and LSST. The method based on detecting highly magnified supernovae reaches an \u223c80\u00a0per\u2009cent completeness in the z and y bands at Xlim &lt; 21. The completeness of lensed SNe search by means of detecting image multiplicity increases with survey depth. The method becomes more complete than that based on magnification for surveys with depths comparable to or larger than the LSST.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903486/stz1516fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903486\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=PUGf36XJSpQAjOJWK8YzEMJd9-2IwangooCsbk~AXXo~VW9scaDZMrSY0cgTXWXkKoe2vUs6XSXjN3OMzjgmQ4UFVceYq40CG6fDjpnnkspvc1M2OWwpZDXzbdbFKi-28RpCImKtiHV8oKiiVfFUr1cgnzxWrzRD42UgZlOE4-Og3ujOTE-skvnFb6G2S4g6eTuvoD1TNgr02poh92uJGKWYnmUI2JLXq9WILXCavNxolwlSzCIBxAHt3dlU-fmEjUuXwlKryapqoSQNDTfcVJseYwUijeDn1LEk6UuC9WFY-1-T86ZelzLWMWwXFdAmPZxj3B68SI7TCBcNIXhYPQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903486&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Completeness of lensed SN candidates found with three different methods, as a function of survey depth in five different bands. The vertical grey bands indicate the depths of ZTF and LSST. The method based on detecting highly magnified supernovae reaches an \u223c80\u00a0per\u2009cent completeness in the <em>z</em> and <em>y</em> bands at <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &lt; 21. The completeness of lensed SNe search by means of detecting image multiplicity increases with survey depth. The method becomes more complete than that based on magnification for surveys with depths comparable to or larger than the LSST.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"136903487\" scrollto-destination=\"136903487\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=ksi1bDMCU9p1OYq4ofU2UuHRKi~AEW8STTKg6HVbmcvDIdv9dCBeMqJVnexMeq6c2egqnjbSiEDOrNOb1Px9~HUaoPexjkLxXCJhL9YcSXtybS~aOpZ0jovThhhgXC6ypfAJDtlG3u3cM3Gb9~85FpO0-ZovAL2cyIOiuXHZpEmdCAxvWONn6zRyiypRO4xN8Cvj44ino--qyAdsaXtvGS9APbHwgGgQUkbCkLUUssd4ikrP1Y127wnYZtxICIzmZTr~CKi09PkWs7nhEq~jc~ia8YT2jAB5vbKj46vNzHD71hyFgdkaCw5yF2lrlFph0EzOOwrtSjixNBCRu2Hfcw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Redshift completeness of lensed type Ia SN candidates found with three different methods, for three limitting magnitudes ilim in the i band. The method based on detecting image multiplicity returns nearly complete redshift samples up to a maximum redshift set by the survey depth. For a reference point, the black curves show redshift distributions of all (non-lensed) or strongly lensed type Ia SNe, both normalized to 1 at z &lt; 3.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903487/stz1516fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903487\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=fG-c5VJV0IdSOkqf1afLgACWc6kjhhGEpBX3rothW6HHnzGvgYokgpod4rmMnRWtgwk-V7TgniumMc1mofYQj8uHHdasf-VudIbDrzHYiO3Y-UazfCVYzMgU078wxkYT325dn4oxO8TNSQlFvPL3kCEBOT4a2jQAOI9yJQ9G~yJm2SbdWpYdoptYldg2MDjTuIhiymXsIwTK5wcL9FvJlg9lOV3d5G8HZs~2X0CiX1Pg~Ga~d37By9mMCFiNjiXBkybcqmm4wOVNoAOM8gPLlOHaDTu0QQdPqbV1yD9V04tdALsda-KmjLDH9SB~7eoZIPBGRs1d6IMYv9Mr4hfU4A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903487&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift completeness of lensed type Ia SN candidates found with three different methods, for three limitting magnitudes <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band. The method based on detecting image multiplicity returns nearly complete redshift samples up to a maximum redshift set by the survey depth. For a reference point, the black curves show redshift distributions of all (non-lensed) or strongly lensed type Ia SNe, both normalized to 1 at <em>z</em> &lt; 3.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=ksi1bDMCU9p1OYq4ofU2UuHRKi~AEW8STTKg6HVbmcvDIdv9dCBeMqJVnexMeq6c2egqnjbSiEDOrNOb1Px9~HUaoPexjkLxXCJhL9YcSXtybS~aOpZ0jovThhhgXC6ypfAJDtlG3u3cM3Gb9~85FpO0-ZovAL2cyIOiuXHZpEmdCAxvWONn6zRyiypRO4xN8Cvj44ino--qyAdsaXtvGS9APbHwgGgQUkbCkLUUssd4ikrP1Y127wnYZtxICIzmZTr~CKi09PkWs7nhEq~jc~ia8YT2jAB5vbKj46vNzHD71hyFgdkaCw5yF2lrlFph0EzOOwrtSjixNBCRu2Hfcw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Redshift completeness of lensed type Ia SN candidates found with three different methods, for three limitting magnitudes ilim in the i band. The method based on detecting image multiplicity returns nearly complete redshift samples up to a maximum redshift set by the survey depth. For a reference point, the black curves show redshift distributions of all (non-lensed) or strongly lensed type Ia SNe, both normalized to 1 at z &lt; 3.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903487/stz1516fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903487\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=fG-c5VJV0IdSOkqf1afLgACWc6kjhhGEpBX3rothW6HHnzGvgYokgpod4rmMnRWtgwk-V7TgniumMc1mofYQj8uHHdasf-VudIbDrzHYiO3Y-UazfCVYzMgU078wxkYT325dn4oxO8TNSQlFvPL3kCEBOT4a2jQAOI9yJQ9G~yJm2SbdWpYdoptYldg2MDjTuIhiymXsIwTK5wcL9FvJlg9lOV3d5G8HZs~2X0CiX1Pg~Ga~d37By9mMCFiNjiXBkybcqmm4wOVNoAOM8gPLlOHaDTu0QQdPqbV1yD9V04tdALsda-KmjLDH9SB~7eoZIPBGRs1d6IMYv9Mr4hfU4A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903487&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Redshift completeness of lensed type Ia SN candidates found with three different methods, for three limitting magnitudes <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band. The method based on detecting image multiplicity returns nearly complete redshift samples up to a maximum redshift set by the survey depth. For a reference point, the black curves show redshift distributions of all (non-lensed) or strongly lensed type Ia SNe, both normalized to 1 at <em>z</em> &lt; 3.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903488 id=\"136903488\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Core-collapse supernovae</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, we show the expected detection rates for lensed core-collapse SNe, divided into four subclasses. As for Type Ia SNe, the method of finding lensed SNe by means of detecting highly magnified transients appears to be more effective for shallow surveys, but it is surpassed by the technique based on image multiplicity for deep surveys. The limiting magnitude of comparable performances of the two methods depends weakly on the SNe type and filter, and it typically falls within a magnitude range between 23 and 24. The exception in this respect are type IIn SNe for which the magnification-based method appears to be more effective up to as high as 25 mag in the <em>g</em> and <em>r</em> bands.</p>                        <a id=\"136903490\" scrollto-destination=\"136903490\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=FQAvSB3E7cVcQUfim9CGa~iUs94Yv8yIa0nTbfC5bTlba8HwSV7RJOMCIe-S206MWfRxsk~Zp7t-yaC3xenZttGbPn30A3g1ESjhCioH5qqb8fQvqM09CDRQL-o4zIRM0q8~EP1vlw2njNpGahUamGipiFwiMfP~7UrIYxISdPbCgNDRLqaBdD7GpVn7nHflKYJ~uQ5bkF10gSZnsH2VuOYsxBBu1uWK8qL0FTZo3UOFhdglDJc4S5dZ4GMxEYWvfUSFLVp3c4s3YnkZdhgVPjd3wwjBOj55qdGj00ZYSpi60HWl~1nADE8vDZ8GDlBXWLqIzV~dTl5t14mUmAEffA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Detection rates of strongly lensed core-collapse SNe (from top left clockwise: IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ibc) as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SN yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. For comparison, the orange curves shows the expected rates for lensed type Ia SNe observed in the i band.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903490/stz1516fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903490\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=MIg1LXYmOIpXghlaaAcxFIdXBVO3lBN1R~6~lD81c8~z5DgabRVlX6Wez2i6c60ejmIERJCG4itAz0p4RsYNHm-hRI5wEL-gKd-X2rlowQy6bsr~UbQmuTDHqcoEor836QJxd6DvV2TvtJYRBmBh7~2v8e~9Rp3hylzt~Isvm8Yfh7vCrenEAxJtHoJpD2gogdTqHopjmHIHTJ0eJfaK0VXme2HvQRzgvcVX8CDr4D2Ylw77iM8JdE2Th73NNPs0a4nUnSNVK4Nhmy7sdBZXEwLPWliwhlJfaeLHRyEXpFqz6ufMuExhqVtT43F35PIvGfT2BTwTpdZjarhpcy4IVg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903490&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detection rates of strongly lensed core-collapse SNe (from top left clockwise: IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ibc) as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SN yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. For comparison, the orange curves shows the expected rates for lensed type Ia SNe observed in the <em>i</em> band.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=FQAvSB3E7cVcQUfim9CGa~iUs94Yv8yIa0nTbfC5bTlba8HwSV7RJOMCIe-S206MWfRxsk~Zp7t-yaC3xenZttGbPn30A3g1ESjhCioH5qqb8fQvqM09CDRQL-o4zIRM0q8~EP1vlw2njNpGahUamGipiFwiMfP~7UrIYxISdPbCgNDRLqaBdD7GpVn7nHflKYJ~uQ5bkF10gSZnsH2VuOYsxBBu1uWK8qL0FTZo3UOFhdglDJc4S5dZ4GMxEYWvfUSFLVp3c4s3YnkZdhgVPjd3wwjBOj55qdGj00ZYSpi60HWl~1nADE8vDZ8GDlBXWLqIzV~dTl5t14mUmAEffA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Detection rates of strongly lensed core-collapse SNe (from top left clockwise: IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ibc) as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SN yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. For comparison, the orange curves shows the expected rates for lensed type Ia SNe observed in the i band.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903490/stz1516fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903490\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=MIg1LXYmOIpXghlaaAcxFIdXBVO3lBN1R~6~lD81c8~z5DgabRVlX6Wez2i6c60ejmIERJCG4itAz0p4RsYNHm-hRI5wEL-gKd-X2rlowQy6bsr~UbQmuTDHqcoEor836QJxd6DvV2TvtJYRBmBh7~2v8e~9Rp3hylzt~Isvm8Yfh7vCrenEAxJtHoJpD2gogdTqHopjmHIHTJ0eJfaK0VXme2HvQRzgvcVX8CDr4D2Ylw77iM8JdE2Th73NNPs0a4nUnSNVK4Nhmy7sdBZXEwLPWliwhlJfaeLHRyEXpFqz6ufMuExhqVtT43F35PIvGfT2BTwTpdZjarhpcy4IVg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903490&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detection rates of strongly lensed core-collapse SNe (from top left clockwise: IIP, IIL, IIn, and Ibc) as a function of survey depth in five different bands, in an all-sky search. The long- and short-dashed curves compare the SN yields expected for two different observational strategies based on detecting image multiplicity or highly magnified SNe. The solid curves show the yields for the hybrid method which maximizes detection rates by means of combining both detection criteria. For comparison, the orange curves shows the expected rates for lensed type Ia SNe observed in the <em>i</em> band.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The orange curves in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> show reference rates for lensed type Ia SNe detectable in the <em>i</em> band. Except for type IIn SNe, the discovery rates of lensed core-collapsed SNe are lower than type Ia by a factor of 2\u20135. A high fraction of luminous type IIn SNe with <em>M</em><sub>B</sub> &lt; \u221220 makes them appreciably easier to detect. Furthermore, the high UV flux of these SNe substantially increases the detection rates in shorter wavelength filters. This considerably reduces the differences between detection rates in the <em>g</em> and <em>y</em> bands, which is otherwise conspicuous for all other SN types. This effect becomes particularly strong at large limiting magnitudes (<em>X</em><sub>lim</sub> &gt; 23.5), where the <em>g</em> band appears to be the most effective filter for detecting lensed type IIn SNe via the magnification method.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The total number of detectable lensed core-collapse SNe exceeds that of type Ia, with the primary contribution coming solely from type IIn SNe. The detection rates of lensed SNe of type IIP, IIL, and Ib/c are systematically lower than type Ia.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903493 id=\"136903493\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Fitting function</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For the purpose of future studies exploring the feasibility of using strongly lensed SNe as cosmological and astrophysical probes, we provide a set of simple fitting functions reproducing the computed detection rates. We find that the logarithm of detection rates can be well fitted by a fourth-degree polynomial, i.e. <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update85119_equ13\" content-id=\"update85119_equ13\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\log _{10}n_{\\rm SN}(\\lt X_{\\rm lim}) &amp; = &amp; \\sum _{i=0}^{i=4}X_{\\mathrm{ i}}(X_{\\rm lim}-22.5)^{i}. \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(13)</span></div>Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> lists best-fitting parameters for different detection strategies, SN types, and filters.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The fitting functions provide accurate approximations to the exact results in a range between <em>X</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 19 and 26 for all cases. The mean precision given by the root mean square averaged over all cases of filters, SN types, and methods is 0.02\u00a0dex.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903496 id=\"136903496\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected detection rates of strongly lensed SNe computed in our work depend on a range of assumptions. The cosmological model, the lens model, and the volumetric rates of type Ia SNe are fairly well constrained by observations and supported by solid theoretical frameworks. On the other hand, the luminosity functions and fractions of different types of SNe, the volumetric rates of core-collapse SNe at high redshifts and the spectral templates of different types of core-collapse SNe (especially type IIn) are less certain and may be a source of additional systematic errors in our estimates. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> shows an example of how modifications in the input luminosity function of type Ia SNe can change the expected discovery rates. Bearing in mind that our results may be subject to improvements in the light of future observations, we stress that the predicted discovery rates of lensed SNe presented here reflect the current state of our knowledge on different types of SNe.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In our calculations, we neglect the effect of microlensing. This is a safe assumption, because due to its stochastic nature, microlensing is expected to have a negligible impact on overall predictions of discovery rates of lensed SNe (Goldstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>). However, the effect does perturb light curves independently in every supernova image, giving rise to additional systematic errors in measurements of relative fluxes in the images and time delays (Pierel\u00a0&amp; Rodney <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). In our comparison of detection methods we do not consider the problem of possible false positive detections. All methods will be affected by a population of faint quasars increasing stochastically their brightness above the detection limit. Moreover, the magnification method can easily confuse non-lensed superluminous SNe with high-redshift lensed candidates. Quantitative analyses of these effects is worth carrying out in the near future.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the following, we compare observational strategies for detecting lensed supernovae in the context of ongoing or upcoming transient surveys and the potential of using lensed SNe for cosmological inference.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903500 id=\"136903500\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Ongoing and upcoming surveys</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strongly lensed SNe will be discovered in appreciable numbers by ongoing and upcoming transient surveys. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> lists the expected discovery rates for the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), LSST, and a hypothetical the Panoramic Survey Telescope and Rapid Response System (Pan-STARRS) survey.</p>                        <a id=\"136903502\" scrollto-destination=\"136903502\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected <em>annual</em> numbers of discovered lensed supernovae in ongoing or upcoming transient surveys. The method based on image multiplicity is ineffective in case case of ZTF and Pan-STARRS, and thus it is omitted in the table. Symbols in parentheses indicate the most effective filter yielding the largest number of detections.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Survey/detection method<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Effective area (deg<sup>2</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ia<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIP<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIL<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ib/c<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIn<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>ZTF/magnification\u00a0</td><td>15 000\u00a0</td><td>2.1 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.37 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.23 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.36 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>3.8 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Pan-STARRS/magnification\u00a0</td><td>3000\u00a0</td><td>0.9 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.20 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.13 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.20 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/magnification\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>61(<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.2 (<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>8.7 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.3 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>184 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/image multiplicity\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>44 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.1 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>5.5 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>88 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/hybrid\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>89 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>16.3 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>11.9 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>15.8 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>210 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Survey/detection method<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Effective area (deg<sup>2</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ia<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIP<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIL<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ib/c<span (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>3.8 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Pan-STARRS/magnification\u00a0</td><td>3000\u00a0</td><td>0.9 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.20 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.13
