(<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>8.7 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.3 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>184 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/image multiplicity\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>44 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.1 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>5.5 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>88 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/hybrid\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>89 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>16.3 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>11.9 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>15.8 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>210 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/136903502\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected <em>annual</em> numbers of discovered lensed supernovae in ongoing or upcoming transient surveys. The method based on image multiplicity is ineffective in case case of ZTF and Pan-STARRS, and thus it is omitted in the table. Symbols in parentheses indicate the most effective filter yielding the largest number of detections.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Survey/detection method<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Effective area (deg<sup>2</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ia<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIP<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIL<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ib/c<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIn<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>ZTF/magnification\u00a0</td><td>15 000\u00a0</td><td>2.1 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.37 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.23 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.36 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>3.8 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Pan-STARRS/magnification\u00a0</td><td>3000\u00a0</td><td>0.9 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.20 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.13 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.20 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/magnification\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>61(<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.2 (<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>8.7 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.3 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>184 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/image multiplicity\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>44 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.1 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>5.5 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>88 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/hybrid\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>89 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>16.3 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>11.9 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>15.8 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>210 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Survey/detection method<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Effective area (deg<sup>2</sup>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ia<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIP<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIL<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type Ib/c<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Type IIn<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>ZTF/magnification\u00a0</td><td>15 000\u00a0</td><td>2.1 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.37 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.23 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.36 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td><td>3.8 (<em>r</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Pan-STARRS/magnification\u00a0</td><td>3000\u00a0</td><td>0.9 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.20 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.13 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.20 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>0.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/magnification\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>61(<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.2 (<em>z</em>)\u00a0</td><td>8.7 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>12.3 (<em>y</em>)\u00a0</td><td>184 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/image multiplicity\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>44 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.1 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>5.5 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>6.8 (<em>i</em>)\u00a0</td><td>88 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LSST/hybrid\u00a0</td><td>20 000\u00a0</td><td>89 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>16.3 (<em>iz</em>)\u00a0</td><td>11.9 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>15.8 (<em>iy</em>)\u00a0</td><td>210 (<em>g</em>)\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/136903502\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">ZTF is an ongoing survey monitoring 15000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in the <em>g</em> and <em>r</em> bands. For the estimation of discovery rates, we assume that all candidates will be detected in the most effective filter, i.e. the <em>r</em> band. A 5\u03c3 limiting magnitude per pointing in this survey is 20.6 (Bellm et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). As a Pan-STARRS-based survey example, we consider a strategy which is alternative to ZTF. The sky coverage is only 20\u00a0per\u2009cent of that in ZTF, but in <em>griz</em> bands with the same cadence as ZTF. All lensed SNe detectable in this survey would be found in the <em>i</em> band for which the survey would reach a 5\u03c3 limiting magnitude of 20.6 per pointing. The potentially more effective <em>z</em> band would not improve detection rates due to its shallower depth of 20.2. Both ZTF and the Pan-STARRS survey operate in the regime of limiting magnitudes at which the only effective detection technique is the magnification method. Therefore, we omit the rates expected for the image multiplicity and hybrid techniques for them in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">LSST will cover about 20\u2009000\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> in 6 <em>ugrizy</em> bands every 2\u20133 weeks with a limiting magnitude of 24 (LSST Science Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Precise estimation of discovery rates relies on details of the observational strategy which is yet to be decided. However, reasonable estimates can be obtained based on the following reasoning. A typical redshift of strongly lensed SNe to be discovered by LSST is <em>z</em>\u00a0= 1. This means that the faintest SNe can be detected only within a time window of about 10\u00a0d (rest frame) around the peak of their light curve (20\u00a0d in the observer frame). In order to satisfy this condition, all detectable SNe should be at least 0.2 mag brighter at the peak than the actual limiting magnitudes of the survey which are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(24.5,\\, 24.2,\\, 23.6,\\, 22.8,\\, 22.0)$|</span> in the <em>grizy</em> bands (mean 5\u03c3 per pointing; based on LSST collaboration\u2019s simulations, baseline2018a run,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> which is the current official reference simulated survey). Then, the expected discovery rate can be found as the maximum rate found for all filters. Since LSST will observe down to limiting magnitudes at which the image multiplicity method becomes effective, we provide rate estimates for all three methods of finding lensed SN candidates. Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> also shows the most effective filter (with the highest rate) for different SN types and detection methods.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Pre-LSST surveys may find about five strongly lensed SNe per year, based solely on the magnification method. The most frequent type will be IIn, followed by Ia. Discovery rates will increase by nearly two orders of magnitude for LSST. It is also clear that the magnification method is expected to yield only about two\u00a0times more discoveries than the image multiplication method. However, both methods will detect lensed SNe at comparable rates when we assume that the measured flux in the magnification methods comes solely from the brightest image (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). Furthermore, keeping in mind that multiply imaged transients do not require follow-up observations confirming their lensing nature (in contrast to highly magnified transients which can be confused with superluminous SNe), we conclude that the image multiplicity method will be the most effective technique for finding lensed transients in LSST data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensed SNe discovered by LSST will be typically detected in the <em>i</em> band as a multiply imaged transient and in the <em>y</em> band (or the <em>z</em> band for type Ia and IIP) as a highly magnified transient (except for type IIn which will be discovered primarily in bluer filters). The difference in the effective discovery band can strengthen the complementarity of the two detection techniques. Considering a hybrid method of finding lensed SNe via image multiplicity in the <em>i</em> band and magnification in the <em>y</em> band (or <em>z</em> for Type Ia and IIP), we find that discovery rates in this approach are higher by 30\u201350\u00a0per\u2009cent than those based solely on magnification.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Except for type IIP SNe, our discovery rates estimated for ZTF and LSST based on the magnification method agree fairly well with analogous predictions obtained by Goldstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). Adopting the same detection conditions and survey parameters for LSST, we also recover fairly closely the rates estimated by Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), with the total number of lensed Type Ia and core-collapse SNe to be discovered by LSST of 32 and 36. These rates are lower by a factor of &gt;10 than those listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and obtained by Goldstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). These differences can be fully accounted for to the stricter detection criteria adopted by Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), i.e. an effective limiting magnitude of 22.6 in the <em>i</em> band (in order to sample light curves at minimum depth of 0.7 mag around the peak) and an effective survey time of 2.5\u00a0yr (accounting for seasonal changes of the surveyed area), and do not signal discrepancies in the basic methodologies in the independent approaches to estimating detection rates. It is worth mentioning that more restrictive selection criteria than those proposed by Oguri\u00a0&amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) are required for obtaining high-quality measurements of gravitational time delays. In particular, a minimum precision of 5\u00a0per\u2009cent and an accuracy of 1\u00a0per\u2009cent in the time delay measurements (if based solely on LSST observations) would reduce the number of lensed type Ia SNe to about 1 per year (Huber et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). This rate can be increased by a factor of 2\u201316 by employing other instruments for follow-up observations.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903508 id=\"136903508\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Observed fractions of supernova types</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> shows predicted fractions of different types of SNe in representative samples of gravitationally lensed SNe expected in transient surveys with a range of limiting magnitudes between 19 and 26.</p>                        <a id=\"136903510\" scrollto-destination=\"136903510\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=DoTEbRgEvGC~vhsu9bfMCorwsXhTJGL59KXWDcXivTWp4SVbchAJNJ69374duux38ySfkWCXKVCONqapWIV7-b3qpNznr6gaIYlZIrvUV1UC5WhkIbGP1OG2tdCpX9aVRktcWNi8OOyOzLIykovuG0TiA~F7O2ina8pvyV8auDn0K86bbCIvJJgQc2SQEIF3~ZYggeX4EuKllC4BZcXnI3j6maqPcYHP90Tg7DltAA8Gy4vYXXpUIh5zr9x~aZanzJYnmEmCmNL~1JFyQqiBHPIdDvV50s6oQlPpJK9VB7XOPQOPhNrkY1a7Y75MqjiobsV1-bBvEckxe1ve7~krbQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fractions of different SN types in samples of gravitationally lensed SNe detected in transient surveys with limiting magnitude ilim in the i band. Gravitationally lensed SNe are detected via magnification (dashed curves) or using the hybrid method (solid curves).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903510/stz1516fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903510\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=LZaryl3SXcNUAeeRgRiMZi-vJTPBNsa8ADJOlC3gsVLJpLBstkD-UOcqYR~JmYL7Z9UmPXmnQGKWVxtse0RFcbF50A7aOkTnRJwcFw5mQMo~OZCVHJrahFmEyXepDsPqkkHh4Zd4TBXMAWKz~jFolg-koQrdFeCHNLAMeOaHWH9rwPduryZPnCqnt1C8PoU8i5cLnjpL8WnVwjXOS1Lf4AEKgf-zxf-KmMpa5pjQoPlrbS48O1L4b-N2FOSr62MjGl-pDetgZHNmvTdO5TRbd0k-yUG8F8gwsFgqlHwX65-EWBGO~KKfvC8GzcZ0ICoS1ikgr~j~8fGDwtdwxUgYqw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903510&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fractions of different SN types in samples of gravitationally lensed SNe detected in transient surveys with limiting magnitude <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band. Gravitationally lensed SNe are detected via magnification (dashed curves) or using the hybrid method (solid curves).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=DoTEbRgEvGC~vhsu9bfMCorwsXhTJGL59KXWDcXivTWp4SVbchAJNJ69374duux38ySfkWCXKVCONqapWIV7-b3qpNznr6gaIYlZIrvUV1UC5WhkIbGP1OG2tdCpX9aVRktcWNi8OOyOzLIykovuG0TiA~F7O2ina8pvyV8auDn0K86bbCIvJJgQc2SQEIF3~ZYggeX4EuKllC4BZcXnI3j6maqPcYHP90Tg7DltAA8Gy4vYXXpUIh5zr9x~aZanzJYnmEmCmNL~1JFyQqiBHPIdDvV50s6oQlPpJK9VB7XOPQOPhNrkY1a7Y75MqjiobsV1-bBvEckxe1ve7~krbQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Fractions of different SN types in samples of gravitationally lensed SNe detected in transient surveys with limiting magnitude ilim in the i band. Gravitationally lensed SNe are detected via magnification (dashed curves) or using the hybrid method (solid curves).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903510/stz1516fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903510\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=LZaryl3SXcNUAeeRgRiMZi-vJTPBNsa8ADJOlC3gsVLJpLBstkD-UOcqYR~JmYL7Z9UmPXmnQGKWVxtse0RFcbF50A7aOkTnRJwcFw5mQMo~OZCVHJrahFmEyXepDsPqkkHh4Zd4TBXMAWKz~jFolg-koQrdFeCHNLAMeOaHWH9rwPduryZPnCqnt1C8PoU8i5cLnjpL8WnVwjXOS1Lf4AEKgf-zxf-KmMpa5pjQoPlrbS48O1L4b-N2FOSr62MjGl-pDetgZHNmvTdO5TRbd0k-yUG8F8gwsFgqlHwX65-EWBGO~KKfvC8GzcZ0ICoS1ikgr~j~8fGDwtdwxUgYqw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903510&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fractions of different SN types in samples of gravitationally lensed SNe detected in transient surveys with limiting magnitude <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band. Gravitationally lensed SNe are detected via magnification (dashed curves) or using the hybrid method (solid curves).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed fractions depend quite weakly on limiting magnitude. The most noticeable trend occurs for type IIP, IIL, and Ibc at large limiting magnitudes for the image multiplicity method. The highest fractions of these supernovae are expected for extremely shallow or deep surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Type Ia and IIn SNe clearly dominate detections, with fractions of about 30\u00a0per\u2009cent each. The prevalence of type IIn SNe becomes even stronger Ia when one includes detections in the <em>g</em> band, the most efficient filter for observing type IIn SNe. We emphasize that the high relative discovery rates of type IIn SNe rely quite strongly on the adopted spectral templates which in turn depend on the extinction correction performed in the analysis of the observational data used here (see Di Carlo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Nevertheless, the high predicted relative detection rates of lensed type IIn SNe is intriguing. The rates and luminosity distribution of type IIn supernovae at high redshift are quite uncertain, theoretically because of their wide range of possible progenitors, including very massive stars in the tail of the initial mass function (e.g. Gal-Yam\u00a0&amp; Leonard <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Smith <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Th\u00f6ne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and observationally, because of their diverse photometric properties (e.g. Taddia et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Richardson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014b</a>; Cappellaro et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Fortunately, lensed type IIn SNe can readily be distinguished from other SNe due to their narrow (and hence high spectroscopic signal-to-noise ratio) Balmer emission lines. Hence, observations of lensed IIn could provide unique insights into their intrinsic properties at high redshift.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=136903514 id=\"136903514\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 Discovery space</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The detection methods considered in this study may also lead to differences in the phase space of lensing configurations. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> shows the distributions of basic lensing parameters of lensed type Ia SNe as a function of limiting <em>i</em>-band magnitude. The green contours shows 10-quantiles of the distributions expected for the hybrid method. The purple and orange curves show the median and a range containing 80\u00a0per\u2009cent of the cases for the magnification and image multiplicity techniques, respectively. We omit results for the image multiplication technique at limiting magnitudes lower than <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 21.5 where the method is far less competitive, with the potential discovery rate smaller than 10\u00a0per\u2009cent of that of the magnification technique. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> also shows the fractions of the different image configurations with two (doubles), three (cusps), and four images (quads).</p>                        <a id=\"136903516\" scrollto-destination=\"136903516\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=DXfePdM37P3eYwex9Y-qCATTrPGZWBXLgb8RJNJnxXDZa6ufprBJ9PSjsPh0XuO~QyQHlP8DtsxLi~Xy8pRxrArLFFvu9luGHot-KiOH0eZwf2vO9AWzPW9lCr3oAw36rMRZ8QdBQS7zBowOGMnuzCL96j~JSrqD-BmRnVZYi9Uw1RaKL3Js73WisLMRG2TFKsFrmjHGRzzC4NvqfLBZ1TRFwrIGy4cEz39FrOaBuRn38kTGaCwlFHHVY8qw3aV1cxFkZELBml7L2wTTC7SfPsUg40-CsANYMnmKjC55ZkDE19g5PdGJAtcnWarOcgpK1DGgPKd6opCT0srUioKfTA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Discovery space of gravitationally lensed type Ia SNe detected with different methods in a single-filter survey with depth ilim in the i band. The panels show distributions of supernova redshift zSN, lens redshift zlens, total magnification \u03bctotal, gravitational time delay averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394t\u3009 and image separation averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394\u03b8\u3009. The green contours show 10-quantiles of the distributions for supernova samples produced by the hybrid method. The purple and orange curves show the median and 80-per\u2009cent probability range of probability distributions for the magnification and image multiplicity methods, respectively. The results for the image multiplicity are shown only for detection rates larger than 10\u00a0per\u2009cent of the corresponding detection rates for the magnification method. The bottom right panel shows fractions of different lensing configurations with two images (doubles), three images (cusps), or four images (quads).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903516/stz1516fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903516\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=sjz9bsGm~EL2smAikIwx56q3ibyyeFyeAz4wmVAQXv5dn4E92Jg81jqaxNOM5ZM7AE51-l5AXAACqHZEh5Rq4FpowEYMjnyWlC3O7uuge8JZ0-S96zGWdtDA97pojBRl1qSFQMZhx6R6A6HYW0t7P9uGgavxZYXLWbxesRJPhudllH5wvP5Dq-bz3QfonfPyVz8jt3mpSlKDXYoTQu2iF6QfQ--2t3syAIe8tMKFlRM5lJYjm-ytOD7VfvmqSB~38-mSHT0Ik3JZZJUXkQROefXk0x9QxNA1lLpoGgPfydWM9TcUrHT48cl66Nt0wVotRifWT~iTa9sRRU9SMwedhQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903516&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Discovery space of gravitationally lensed type Ia SNe detected with different methods in a single-filter survey with depth <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band. The panels show distributions of supernova redshift <em>z</em><sub>SN</sub>, lens redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub>, total magnification \u03bc<sub>total</sub>, gravitational time delay averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394<em>t</em>\u3009 and image separation averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394\u03b8\u3009. The green contours show 10-quantiles of the distributions for supernova samples produced by the hybrid method. The purple and orange curves show the median and 80-per\u2009cent probability range of probability distributions for the magnification and image multiplicity methods, respectively. The results for the image multiplicity are shown only for detection rates larger than 10\u00a0per\u2009cent of the corresponding detection rates for the magnification method. The bottom right panel shows fractions of different lensing configurations with two images (doubles), three images (cusps), or four images (quads).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=DXfePdM37P3eYwex9Y-qCATTrPGZWBXLgb8RJNJnxXDZa6ufprBJ9PSjsPh0XuO~QyQHlP8DtsxLi~Xy8pRxrArLFFvu9luGHot-KiOH0eZwf2vO9AWzPW9lCr3oAw36rMRZ8QdBQS7zBowOGMnuzCL96j~JSrqD-BmRnVZYi9Uw1RaKL3Js73WisLMRG2TFKsFrmjHGRzzC4NvqfLBZ1TRFwrIGy4cEz39FrOaBuRn38kTGaCwlFHHVY8qw3aV1cxFkZELBml7L2wTTC7SfPsUg40-CsANYMnmKjC55ZkDE19g5PdGJAtcnWarOcgpK1DGgPKd6opCT0srUioKfTA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Discovery space of gravitationally lensed type Ia SNe detected with different methods in a single-filter survey with depth ilim in the i band. The panels show distributions of supernova redshift zSN, lens redshift zlens, total magnification \u03bctotal, gravitational time delay averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394t\u3009 and image separation averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394\u03b8\u3009. The green contours show 10-quantiles of the distributions for supernova samples produced by the hybrid method. The purple and orange curves show the median and 80-per\u2009cent probability range of probability distributions for the magnification and image multiplicity methods, respectively. The results for the image multiplicity are shown only for detection rates larger than 10\u00a0per\u2009cent of the corresponding detection rates for the magnification method. The bottom right panel shows fractions of different lensing configurations with two images (doubles), three images (cusps), or four images (quads).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903516/stz1516fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903516\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=sjz9bsGm~EL2smAikIwx56q3ibyyeFyeAz4wmVAQXv5dn4E92Jg81jqaxNOM5ZM7AE51-l5AXAACqHZEh5Rq4FpowEYMjnyWlC3O7uuge8JZ0-S96zGWdtDA97pojBRl1qSFQMZhx6R6A6HYW0t7P9uGgavxZYXLWbxesRJPhudllH5wvP5Dq-bz3QfonfPyVz8jt3mpSlKDXYoTQu2iF6QfQ--2t3syAIe8tMKFlRM5lJYjm-ytOD7VfvmqSB~38-mSHT0Ik3JZZJUXkQROefXk0x9QxNA1lLpoGgPfydWM9TcUrHT48cl66Nt0wVotRifWT~iTa9sRRU9SMwedhQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903516&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Discovery space of gravitationally lensed type Ia SNe detected with different methods in a single-filter survey with depth <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>i</em> band. The panels show distributions of supernova redshift <em>z</em><sub>SN</sub>, lens redshift <em>z</em><sub>lens</sub>, total magnification \u03bc<sub>total</sub>, gravitational time delay averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394<em>t</em>\u3009 and image separation averaged over all image pairs \u3008\u0394\u03b8\u3009. The green contours show 10-quantiles of the distributions for supernova samples produced by the hybrid method. The purple and orange curves show the median and 80-per\u2009cent probability range of probability distributions for the magnification and image multiplicity methods, respectively. The results for the image multiplicity are shown only for detection rates larger than 10\u00a0per\u2009cent of the corresponding detection rates for the magnification method. The bottom right panel shows fractions of different lensing configurations with two images (doubles), three images (cusps), or four images (quads).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitationally lensed supernovae to be found in ongoing pre-LSST shallow surveys will be extremely magnified. For a limiting magnitude of 20.6 (depth of ZTF), the expected mean magnification is 20 and a 10\u00a0per\u2009cent tail of the distribution includes cases with magnifications exceeding 100. For shallower surveys, the expected magnification become substantially higher with the mean reaching \u03bc\u00a0= 100 at <em>i</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 19.5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected lensing properties of lensed SNe detected via magnification pose a challenge to using them as cosmological probes. In particular, the typical time delays for lensed SNe found in pre-LSST surveys are below 10\u00a0d and typical image separations will hardly exceed the arcsecond scale. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> demonstrates that LSST or deeper surveys \u2013 with typical time delays always below 10\u00a0d \u2013 can hardly mitigate this problem. In this respect, the image multiplicity method appears to be more promising. When applied to LSST-like surveys (<em>i</em><sub>lim</sub>\u00a0= 23.5), the method is expected to find lensed SNe with the mean time delay of 20\u00a0d (and a 10\u00a0per\u2009cent tail of the distribution with time delays at least 60\u00a0d) and typical image separations larger than 1 arcsec. Undoubtedly, this increases the potential for using lensed SNe to place robust cosmological constraints.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Time delays and image separations are not the only differences between the populations of lensed SNe found via magnification and image multiplicity. We also find that the image multiplicity method is more sensitive to SNe and lens galaxies at lower redshifts. There is also a clear difference in terms of image configuration. A much larger fraction of lensed supernovae found via image multiplicity are doubles, whereas for the magnification methods the numbers of quads and doubles are comparable. Unsurprisingly, both methods exhibit an increasing (decreasing) trend in the fraction of doubles (quads) with increasing limiting magnitude. The fraction of cups is at the sub-per\u2009cent level for the image magnification methods, whereas it reaches a 10-per cent level for the magnification technique.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the context of discussing the future phase space of lensing configurations, it is interesting to consider the case of the gravitationally lensed sn iPTF16geu. The sn was discovered in a relatively shallow survey. In this respect, its high magnification of \u03bc<sub>total</sub> \u223c 50 is not surprising. However, the observed magnification turns out to be at odds with the theoretical expectations when the redshift of the sn is taken into account (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Goldstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>). In order to address this tension, we compute 2D credibility contours for redshifts and gravitational magnifications of all lensed SNe detectable in a transient survey equivalent to the iPTF. As a nominal depth of the survey, we consider either 20.5 or 20.0 in the <em>r</em> band. The latter is a more appropriate choice when one requires good observations of light curves around the peak (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The SN was discovered as a peculiarly bright, initially unresolved, transient; therefore, it is justified to employ the magnification method as an effective approach to finding lensed transients in the iPTF survey. As shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>, the tension between iPTF16geu and theoretical predictions is at a quite modest level of 2\u03c3. We conclude that the peculiar lensing configuration of iPTF16geu can be simply a statistical fluke. However, the flux ratio anomalies between observed brightness of the images and the best-fitting lens model pose a serious problem because the discrepancy seems too large to be ascribed to microlensing (Yahalomi, Schechter\u00a0&amp; Wambsganss <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"136903521\" scrollto-destination=\"136903521\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=lSfaDMHUjnjKvA6kAH9~SpXlOHouxbwCVFf-R4oHsti0LinEgOKIWH6E6vgxMnPsumEDw76IuNoXmWwhJ~0T4VtpIk61NGpI~9~nEVrlUN09fAD~bsI2MoV4vGmSugfHQYNVCxpJysZlBSY41m1d7fzu0x~49LAQa0kTRmTsXK9ntR7emjfY8zsikz1Lj6TT3AeI9-M7IQhYS8C7BwTXazbUMYiry1EwWQItGAyIqeiCtmi2iRXGXOi07Jb9jJzvKtZum0BRwYsphG9jclsCI753A0nt3LYUCFGV9ne3QzEL8lioIztvucP4NTQsS5dwvc2O8Msf3AAiyx30vZsDrA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The expected distribution of the total magnification and redshift (in the form of 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3 credibility contours) of lensed SNe detectable in the iPTF survey with limiting magnitude rlim in the r band, compared to the measured parameters of observed gravitationally lensed SNe iPTF16geu. The observed SNe lies well within a 2\u03c3 contour.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903521/stz1516fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903521\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=bORhLDH7ojM~zdOw2py4we7QtqgntnNc9LPnErX8up6bE0oYawcn4zjfWnT8Wde1cVe5KIqS2rHRv6SA05NeweFjCSmbIGlJFPbtXES692FdTB4oZw6jrzSRsrJae2-NyFHxv46M3TV2FtEw7dGj3sNWQxHSsO3EOKlUZcslZ~t-ds3MDYNfBUKfisPSBZtAeKEaalQvGDPDGHMd5FV9xYv8Prlj-EVxM53yez-8kaTTzOpYTw90BiSt7IJ65PtPP-E45ryOLk10Lz4U90QEW5bMJQ6neCUtMdAQHWhwhd5Tt~C8naTvQBbWND2zSTmdc8dYha4eD94oSb~mX-7gqw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903521&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected distribution of the total magnification and redshift (in the form of 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3 credibility contours) of lensed SNe detectable in the iPTF survey with limiting magnitude <em>r</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>r</em> band, compared to the measured parameters of observed gravitationally lensed SNe iPTF16geu. The observed SNe lies well within a 2\u03c3 contour.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/m_stz1516fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&amp;Signature=lSfaDMHUjnjKvA6kAH9~SpXlOHouxbwCVFf-R4oHsti0LinEgOKIWH6E6vgxMnPsumEDw76IuNoXmWwhJ~0T4VtpIk61NGpI~9~nEVrlUN09fAD~bsI2MoV4vGmSugfHQYNVCxpJysZlBSY41m1d7fzu0x~49LAQa0kTRmTsXK9ntR7emjfY8zsikz1Lj6TT3AeI9-M7IQhYS8C7BwTXazbUMYiry1EwWQItGAyIqeiCtmi2iRXGXOi07Jb9jJzvKtZum0BRwYsphG9jclsCI753A0nt3LYUCFGV9ne3QzEL8lioIztvucP4NTQsS5dwvc2O8Msf3AAiyx30vZsDrA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The expected distribution of the total magnification and redshift (in the form of 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3 credibility contours) of lensed SNe detectable in the iPTF survey with limiting magnitude rlim in the r band, compared to the measured parameters of observed gravitationally lensed SNe iPTF16geu. The observed SNe lies well within a 2\u03c3 contour.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/136903521/stz1516fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"136903521\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/487/3/10.1093_mnras_stz1516/1/stz1516fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465012&Signature=bORhLDH7ojM~zdOw2py4we7QtqgntnNc9LPnErX8up6bE0oYawcn4zjfWnT8Wde1cVe5KIqS2rHRv6SA05NeweFjCSmbIGlJFPbtXES692FdTB4oZw6jrzSRsrJae2-NyFHxv46M3TV2FtEw7dGj3sNWQxHSsO3EOKlUZcslZ~t-ds3MDYNfBUKfisPSBZtAeKEaalQvGDPDGHMd5FV9xYv8Prlj-EVxM53yez-8kaTTzOpYTw90BiSt7IJ65PtPP-E45ryOLk10Lz4U90QEW5bMJQ6neCUtMdAQHWhwhd5Tt~C8naTvQBbWND2zSTmdc8dYha4eD94oSb~mX-7gqw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=136903521&ar=5518361&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stz1516fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The expected distribution of the total magnification and redshift (in the form of 1\u03c3 and 2\u03c3 credibility contours) of lensed SNe detectable in the iPTF survey with limiting magnitude <em>r</em><sub>lim</sub> in the <em>r</em> band, compared to the measured parameters of observed gravitationally lensed SNe iPTF16geu. The observed SNe lies well within a 2\u03c3 contour.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903522 id=\"136903522\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have compared different observational strategies for detecting gravitationally lensed SNe in massive transient surveys. The strategies rely on finding multiply imaged transients or highly magnified SNe (deduced via comparing observed magnitudes to fiducial magnitudes of a type Ia SN located in the apparent host galaxy). Adopting state-of-the-art models of lens galaxies constrained by the SDSS data and the standard cosmological \u039bCDM mode, we have calculated detection rates for each method in five <em>grizy</em> bands for the main SN classes including: type Ia, core-collapse SNe types IIP, IIL, Ibc, and IIn. We provide simple fitting functions approximating the computed rates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We find that detecting lensed supernovae as strongly magnified transients is the only effective detection method working for shallow pre-LSST surveys with limiting magnitudes smaller than 22. However, the expected yields saturate at limiting magnitudes of about 23.0\u201323.5 (depending on SN type and filter) where lensed supernovae are more likely to be fainter than a fiducial type Ia SN in the apparent host galaxies (lens galaxy). At this limiting magnitude, the magnification and image multiplicity method yield comparable numbers of lensed SNe. SNe found by the two methods are to a large extent independent; therefore, a noticeable improvement of discovery rates can be achieved by combining the two methods. The resulting hybrid method increases the yields by 50\u00a0per\u2009cent at limiting magnitudes corresponding to comparable rates expected for the two primary methods. For larger limiting magnitudes \u2273 23.5, the image multiplicity method completely surpasses the performance of the magnification technique.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detection rates depend strongly on filter. Except for type IIn, discovery rates decrease with decreasing effective wavelength. An inverse trend found for type IIn SNe results from the presence of strong UV flux and a relatively higher incidence of luminous SNe with <em>M</em><sub>B</sub> &lt; \u221220. In the overall counts of gravitationally lensed SNe, type IIn will be the most common class followed by type Ia, regardless of the adopted detection method. The rates are dominated by intrinsically bright SNe; therefore, the robustness of our predictions rely on accurate modelling of high-luminosity tails of the SN luminosity functions, currently approximated by Gaussian distributions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Revisiting the initial comparison between the image multiplicity and magnification methods made by Goldstein\u00a0&amp; Nugent (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we find that detecting lensed SNe via image multiplicity is as efficient as the magnification method at the limiting magnitudes of LSST and it surpasses the latter for deeper surveys. Moreover, strongly lensed SNe found via image multiplicity are also characterized by longer time delays and larger image separations than systems found via magnification. This makes the image multiplicity method a more appealing observational strategy for LSST when considering the potential of using lensed SNe as cosmological probes. It is also worth mentioning that the image multiplicity approach does not rely on follow-up observations and it can be naturally applied to self-contained massive surveys without auxiliary imaging observations. In contrast, candidates for lensed SNe selected via magnification naturally require follow-up observations to confirm their the lensing nature.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We estimate that ZTF with a depth of 20.6 in the <em>r</em> band will detect 1.9 type Ia 4.1 core-collapse (primarily IIn) lensed SNe per year. Analogous computations for LSST yield 44 type Ia and 106 core-collapse (primarily IIn) lensed SNe per year, detected via image multiplicity. The hybrid method will allow to increase these rates to 89 and 254 detections per year for type Ia and core collapse, respectively. Core-collapse lensed SNe will be dominated by type IIn with relative fraction of 80\u00a0per\u2009cent.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903528 id=\"136903528\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We are highly indebted to the referee, Prasenjit Saha, for his insightful comments and helpful suggestions. This work was supported by a VILLUM FONDEN Investigator grant to JH (project number 16599).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=136903530 id=\"136903530\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361:20035948\" "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019MNRAS.487.3342W", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Incomplete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "Strongly lensed supernovae (SNe) can be detected as multiply imaged or highly magnified transients. In order to compare the performances of these two observational strategies, we calculate expected discovery rates as a function of survey depth in five grizy filters and for different classes of SNe (types Ia, IIP, IIL, Ibc, and IIn). We find that detections via magnification is the only effective strategy for relatively shallow pre-LSST (Large Synoptic Sky Survey) surveys. For survey depths about the LSST capacity, both strategies yield comparable numbers of lensed SNe. SN samples from the two methods are to a large extent independent and combining them increases detection rates by about 50 per cent. While the number of lensed SNe detectable via magnification saturates at the limiting magnitudes of LSST, detection rates of multiply imaged SN still go up drastically at increasing survey depth. Comparing potential discovery spaces, we find that lensed SNe found via image multiplicity exhibit longer time delays and larger image separations making them more suitable for cosmological constraints than their counterparts found via magnification. We provide useful fitting functions approximating the computed discovery rates for different SN classes and detection methods. We find that the Zwicky Transient Factory will find about two type Ia and four core-collapse lensed SNe per year at a limiting magnitude of 20.6 in the r band. Applying a hybrid method which combines searching for highly magnified or multiply imaged transients, we find that LSST will detect 89 type Ia and 254 core-collapse lensed SNe per year. In all cases, lensed core-collapsed SNe will be dominated by type IIn SNe contributing to 80 per cent of the total counts, although this prediction relies quite strongly on the adopted spectral templates for this class of SNe. Revisiting the case of the lensed SN iPTF16geu, we find that it is consistent within the 2\u03c3 contours of predicted redshifts and magnifications for the intermediate Palomar Transient Factory survey.", "start_page": "3342", "authors": ["Wojtak, Rados\u0142aw", "Hjorth, Jens", "Gall, Christa"], "issn": "0035-8711", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1903.07687", "Title": "Magnified or multiply imaged? - Search strategies for gravitationally lensed supernovae in wide-field surveys", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "methods: statistical", "supernovae: general", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "volume": "487", "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019MNRAS.487.3342W", "end_page": "3355", "number": "3", "publication_year": "2019/08/1", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stz1516", "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "author_address": ["AA(DARK, Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, Lyngbyvej 2, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark), AB(DARK, Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, Lyngbyvej 2, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark), AC(DARK, Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, Lyngbyvej 2, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark)"]}, "Action": "Scanned and processed all tables", "Status": "Complete", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2019MNRAS.487.3342W/PUB_HTML"}
